—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Did the former Government, in which the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer, deliberately run an overvalued exchange rate to serve an anti-inflation purpose? Did that policy leave Australia with an excessive external imbalance and cause the destruction of our international competitiveness? What action has been taken by the Government to correct this position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is in the affirmative on the first two parts of the question. With respect to the third part of the question, the Government has undertaken fundamental policy changes to try to deal with the massive external imbalance bequeathed to us by the former Government through its failure to run a competitive economy for so long. The terms involved in that massive change in the policy settings were: Firstly, a floating of the exchange rate and its freefall to a level which has restored our competitiveness; secondly, a wages policy outcome the magnitude of which has made Australia comparable with the most flexible labour markets in the world; and, thirdly, a slowing of domestic demand in the economy in 1985 to try to make our domestic economy compatible with the deterioration of our external accounts. Last week the Leader of the Opposition said:

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer proffered the totally erroneous proposition that Australia's current account deficit problems were generated during the years that the Fraser Government was in office. That is wrong. It is one of the great pieces of mythology that this Government is trying to develop.

The fact is that it is right. For the benefit of honourable members I table the extract from the 1985-86 Budget Paper No. 1, page 46, which shows the current account deficit in 1981-82 at 6 per cent and declining to 3.9 per cent in 1982-83; the decline occurred under the weight of the recession, because imports fell off so dramatically as a result of the slack demand inside the economy. I also table a refutation of the claim by the former Treasurer that the Government of which he was a member did not use the exchange rate for anti-inflation purposes. I table an extract from the 1980-81 Budget Paper No. 1, which says, on page 52:

The expected larger surplus on private sector foreign exchange transactions will place upward pressure on money supply growth but will also provide a further opportunity for external policy to assist in containing inflationary pressures.

External policy can mean only one thing in the context of a managed exchange rate-that is, management of the rate. The former Government managed the rate and kept it over-valued. This tore the guts out of our agricultural industry, tore the hell out of our manufacturing sector and rendered large slabs of our import competing industries an industrial cemetery. Because honourable members opposite had no wages policy, and they still have not, and because they had no decent incomes policy, and they still have not, the former Government over-valued the exchange rate as a crude anti-inflation weapon. The consequence is in the current account figure for 1981-82 which is at 6 per cent of gross domestic product and the obvious deterioration which was there until this Government placed some demand on the economy and imports started responding again. I refute, if you like, the two refutations-that is, that the former Government did not over-value the exchange rate for some anti-inflationary purpose, and that Australia's lack of competitiveness and its current account problems stem from the policies of the previous Government, as evidenced by a 6 per cent of GDP current account deficit in 1981-82.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister will recall commenting, after the acquittal of Mr Justice Murphy early last week, that it was his expectation that Mr Justice Murphy would return to the High Court. —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Has his attention been drawn to an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald in which the national co-ordinator of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation, Shane Houston, accuses him of putting at risk the health of Aboriginal people by failing to implement a national program to eradicate trachoma? If so, can the Minister advise the House on the accuracy of that article?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the report in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald. Both allegations are false. The facts are as follows: I commissioned a report in April last year to examine the effectiveness of a program to eradicate trachoma and improve eye health among Aborigines. It was the first time that such a comprehensive statistical investigation had taken place since 1980. The trachoma report, responsibility for which was primarily in the hands of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation, was expected in July 1985. It was not in fact received until October of last year. On receving the report I immediately circulated it to Aboriginal health organisations, community controlled organisations, State health authorities and services in which Aboriginal people were employed in trachoma programs outside the purview of NAIHO. We have been waiting upon the response of all of those authorities.

ANSWER.PARA: It has to be understood that the report that has come from NAIHO basically recommends that that organisation should be responsible for the entire control of the trachoma program, that it should receive full funding and that it should be administered from Sydney. Whatever the problems of trachoma are, there is not much evidence of it being a problem in Sydney or in New South Wales. Basically I think Mr Houston's motives in this matter were to pre-empt a decision which he knows will be made at a meeting timed for this week to which the relevant Aboriginal State trachoma committees and NAIHO are being invited to confer and to make recommendations as to the best way in which the report should be implemented. It has to be understood that in the meantime I have received representations from individual members of this House and from Aboriginal services saying that they are opposed to the total control of this program passing to NAIHO. Their view is that, where an effective service is being provided for the treatment of trachoma by a State authority or a health organisation outside the purview of NAIHO, that service ought to continue to be maintained and NAIHO ought to be concentrating on those areas where there is not an effective delivery of service. Basically it is not true to say that there has been any waste of funds. As I say, I regret that the statement has been made. It really is an attempt to pre-empt a decision which will be made by me this week in conjunction with the widest possible range of authorities and Aboriginal people who have worked in the field of trachoma eradication.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I ask the honourable gentleman as first law officer: Does the return tomorrow of Mr Justice Murphy to the High Court of Australia have his full confidence and support?

—Has the Prime Minister seen reports that the Leader of the Opposition is calling for the end of the accord as a necessary condition for economic growth and improved living standards? Will the Prime Minister inform the House of the Government's position in relation to this claim?
—I thank the honourable member for his question without notice.
—Is it really without notice?

—Yes. It is a very important question. I have not been able to keep up with this latest observation of the Leader of the Opposition. One really needs a very sophisticated radar set to follow the Leader of the Opposition in this whole area of wages policy. Members of the Opposition have been labouring away for month after month on this question of industrial relations policy and wages policy. They have had one fight, one brawl, after another. It looked as though they had it altogether about two weeks ago and then, just a matter of a few days before its release, they had to make another fundamental change in it. As I understand it-and I say this, of course, subject to the greatest qualification-they have now reached a position whereby in the small firms category-they say arbitrarily that a firm is small if it has 50 or less employees but is not small if it has 50 or more-the employees and the boss can get together and have an arrangement that will not be subject to registration in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. We are going to have a bifurcated industrial relations system in this country that pays no attention at all to the realities of the Australian economy and the Australian industrial relations system. It is a plan which, even with the highly controlled neutralisation policy which the Opposition has undertaken, will receive no support in important areas of the Australian business community. Why? Because the Australian community is the beneficiary of the operation of the accord, which in the last three years in this country has brought unrivalled results. Never before in the history of this country, with the level of economic growth averaging 6 per cent per annum and a 600,000 increase in jobs, would we have had the restraint in wages which, in fact, has come about under the accord. This has seen a return of profitability to the levels at the end of the 1960s and the beginning of the 1970s. This has seen a return of Australian competitiveness to the best position for 15 years. That is what the accord has brought. It has brought unparalleled prosperity, record economic growth and record employment growth in this country. It is a measure of the perspicacity and the economic capacity of the mob opposite that they would throw that down the gurgler. There is only one thing that is going down the gurgler; and that is the Opposition's reputation for economic competence and responsibility.

—I refer the Prime Minister to his interview on the Sunday program yesterday when he claimed that the significance of Australian relations with Indonesia had been exaggerated. On what basis did the Prime Minister make that claim? Does the Prime Minister not agree that the quality and depth of our relations with our closest Asian neighbour, with a population of 160 million, enormous economic potential and influence in the Association of South East Asian Nations and the Islamic world, are anything other than of the highest priority for any Australian government of any political colour?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I stand absolutely by what I said on the program yesterday. I was trying to indicate that in some quarters in Australia an absolute pre-eminence had been given to the relationship but, more importantly, that there was a feeling that perhaps more could be obtained from the relationship than the realities of our differing cultures and differing experiences would intrinsically allow to be extracted. Let me make our position quite clear so that I can destroy at the outset the quite stupid position of the Leader of the Opposition that not enough work is being done on the relationship by establishing that from the very first day of office the Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, and I addressed ourselves to this question and that within a matter of weeks of our coming to office the Foreign Minister went to Indonesia and began the establishment of what had been an improvement in the relationship. I followed that up within a matter of months with my visit there which, apart from a visit to Papua New Guinea, was the first visit by me as Prime Minister to any foreign country. That initial work by Bill Hayden and me has been consistently followed, particularly by the Foreign Minister, since.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no doubt that Mr Hayden has established a constructive relationship with his counterpart, Dr Mochtar. We will continue to do that. No objective analysis of the three years of this Government could come to any conclusion other than that this Government has consistently attempted responsibly to establish a constructive relationship. What I was saying then-it is the third time I have said this in the last week or so-is that I believe that the people of Australia would expect to get, and certainly they are going to get, from this Government a position in which we will continue to establish a constructive relationship with a country of 160 million people, which by any standard of assessment is an important relationship-no one is trying to deny that; we do not deny that-but in the attempt to establish that constructive relationship no government that I lead will accept a situation in which, given all the attempts that we make, if there is what we see as a capricious act by those in authority in Indonesia we will simply say: `Oh, well, that is okay. We have no comment to make about'.

Particularly at the core of this issue is that there must be an acceptance by the authorities in Indonesia of the nature of the Australian society. This is a society which has its imperfections, but one distinguishing characteristic of it is the freedom of the Press. This is not just something which one verbalises by saying: `There it is-the freedom of the Press'. It means something as far as we are concerned; and it is something that we must protect at all costs. We must say to our friends in Indonesia that they must understand this characteristic of the Australian society.

In the immediate aftermath of the reaction of the Indonesian authorities to the publication of the article in the Sydney Morning Herald, there were two reactions from the Opposition. The Leader of the National Party of Australia wanted to declare war tomorrow. The Leader of the Opposition said we had to be even more understanding. As far as this Government is concerned, we will not declare war tomorrow and we will not accept any capricious action and say: `We will not put our position'. We will put the position of Australia and we will put it in the context of going about the hard, undramatic, unremitting task of bilateral relationships, through the Minister for Foreign Affairs and other Ministers, in an attempt to get the relationship on a basis which will protect and advance the interests of the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. I refer to an article in the Melbourne Sun of 30 April which quotes a Mr George West, a senior executive of the company Ansell International, as admitting that certain types of plastic become unstable when treated with irradiation. As Mr West also said, it is up to manufacturers to ensure that the products that Ansell irradiates are suitable for the process, I ask: Does this company deal in the processing of condoms and are these subjected to irradiation treatment? In light of the Government's nationwide assault on the drug crisis and the apparent lack of public information about the food irradiation processing plan, will the Minister advise the House of the steps he can or will take to stop these dangerous practices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that I am not briefed and able to comment on the question of the irradiation of condoms. But I will endeavour to address the other issues raised in the honourable member's question.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no doubt that certain plastics, when wrapped with foods which have been treated in different ways, may become unstable. It is not, of course, only a problem relating to irradiated food. There has always been a problem with different sorts of plastics and their use in the wrapping of food. We have heard about other instances of this previously. But I am informed that certain plastics do produce instabilities in relation to irradiated food.

It is important to take this opportunity to correct some of the misinformation that has been spread about the issue of the irradiation of food. Let me say that the Federal Government has no intention of introducing legislation on food irradiation. It is true that the Public Health Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council has recently developed a model food standard for food irradiation. The National Health and Medical Research Council advises both the Federal Government and State governments. As I understand, this request came some years ago to the National Health and Medical Research Council both from some of the States and some industrialists interested in this process. For the last three or four years the Public Health Committee has been working with international bodies to develop a standard, which is advice given to the Federal Government and also to the State governments. The model that has been developed is based on the international standard developed and endorsed by the Codex Alimentarius Commission of the World Health Organisation and the Food and Agriculture Organisation. It is also the intention of NHMRC to provide an information paper to the public to discuss the whole issue of food irradiation. That will enable a proper and informed debate to take place in this community before any State government makes any decision to proceed with decisions in relation to food irradiation. Because I regard the issue as one of considerable importance to the community, and at the request of some of my Caucus colleagues, I asked that the standard that has been prepared be referred to a full meeting of the National Health and Medical Research Council in view of some of the issues that have been raised in relation to it so that, at its next meeting, the National Health and Medical Research Council will be able to overview the whole matter.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Will the Minister inform the House of the actions taken by the Government in relation to the important question of industrial democracy in this country? Further, can the Minister advise when he anticipates that the Green Paper on this subject will be released?

—The development of industrial democracy is an important plank in this Government's industrial relations platform. It is a matter which some people on the other side gave some credence to at some time during the period of the previous Government, but never delivered very much. It is something which this Government intends to deliver. Industrial democracy basically means that there is greater capacity for people in work places to have greater say in the factors which affect their working life. We believe that a fully-fledged democracy ought to extend to the work place and provide a capacity for working people to have a greater say than in many cases occurs at present. The way in which industrial democracy can be introduced is multifarious. We are in the process of developing a Green Paper, which will shortly be available, which will spell out various ways in which such a policy could be implemented in this country. When that is produced I hope that it will receive a thorough analysis from the other side on the basis of looking to develop industrial democracy in this country and not the normal knocking exercise that one gets. This is a policy I believe which is very much in the interests of better industrial relations in this country. I hope that certain people on the other side who have given some support to this in the past will be able to persuade their colleagues to support it in the future.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor sought leave to table a paper. That is not the Chair's prerogative; the House gives leave. Is leave granted?

—Order! I have to inform the House that we have present in the gallery today Mr Fred Osborne, a former Minister in this House and the honourable member for Evans. On behalf of the members of the House, I bid him welcome.

—Will the Minister for Communications inform the House when the people of regional Australia can expect additional commercial television services, as was promised by the Government over two years ago?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Goldstein for his question. I think it is interesting because there is an implication of some delay. I think it is worth reflecting where we were in this area when the Hawke Labor Government was swept to power in March 1983. At that stage the then Government was really like a rabbit in a spotlight-it was totally spellbound, blind and did not know where it was going. At that stage it had not even faced the issue of the remote area commercial television services. There had been an implication of a Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service II which the honourable member for Murray spoke about from time to time in Opposition. The former Government really had no idea where it was going. In relation to the remote commercial television services this government adopted the proposal which was the preferred option of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. That solution was known as the regional solution which involved a consortia of regional stations providing that remote commercial television service.

ANSWER.PARA: We are well aware of the fact that the regional areas of Australia, as opposed to the remote areas, have not received the same television services as the capital cities of this country which, of course, with the exception of Perth, have three commercial television services, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service. The difficulty is, of course, to bring about equalisation of those services whilst at the same time protecting the interests of the viewers and the industry. The announcement that the honourable member for Goldstein refers to has been delayed because of the fact that balancing factors have to be weighed up, and I would be hopeful that there would be an announcement on that matter certainly within the next month.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES INTRASTATE AIR SERVICES: SYDNEY AIRPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Aviation. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the report of the Riley Committee into Intrastate Air Services in New South Wales, which recommends a significant increase in the number of air services between 12 major regional centres and Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport? Has the Minister noted the warning in that report that increasing congestion will be inevitable at Sydney Airport unless its runway and terminal capacities are urgently upgraded? Will the Minister now agree to the construction of a parallel runway and the earlier than planned installation of new radar so that Sydney can retain its status as the premier international airport of Australia and to allow the Riley recommendations to be implemented and permit better air services for people in regional New South Wales?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to those Press reports. We have not received a copy of the report. I understand the report was delivered to the New South Wales Minister for Transport--
—I believe it was released in the New South Wales Parliament last week.
—I understand that it was received by the New South Wales Minister towards the end of last week and it is not proposed to table the report before the State House resumes in September.
—Whatever it is, it is out in the public.
—When the honourable member gets a copy I would like one, thank you very much. This Government has not yet received a copy, and I do not know under what timetable I will receive a copy.
—It was probably lost in the post.

—I do not believe that. It is just the honourable member's rotten suspicious mind again. One set of recommendations in the report apparently goes to intrastate licensing in New South Wales. I suppose that is in accord with the very progressive policy followed by this Government in the upgrading of country airports to jet standard. The suggestion in the report is that, since there has been an increase in the availability of jet airports, we ought to be seeing in New South Wales a movement towards hub and spoking, a concentration on the lesser services feeding into those jet airports that have been upgraded by this Government-airports such as those at Albury, Wagga Wagga, Tamworth, Casino and, in a few months, Coffs Harbour, and even Bundaberg in Queensland. That is a policy followed by this Government to give better air service to country Australia. That recommendation, obviously, is one simply for the New South Wales Government. In respect of Sydney, I can understand what the Committee is trying to achieve there. If there were more aircraft and air services operating on a hubbing and spoking system into the jet airports in New South Wales it would mean that country people could have a faster service into Sydney by jet aircraft from those hubbed airports. That would reduce the number of aircraft operating into Sydney.

ANSWER.PARA: The other matters raised by the honourable member go to the improved utilisation of Sydney Airport, which is a policy of this Government. As I have said so many times in respect of transport and aviation, the days of throwing money at problems are over. The Opposition cannot have it both ways. It cannot in the morning be screaming for this Government to reduce expenditure, to reduce the deficit by $2 billion a year, and in the afternoon be calling for more expenditure. Those days are gone. The exercise is to improve the efficiency and utilisation of the existing investment. In Sydney we will be doing that in a number of ways. There is a program under way to improve taxiways whereby we can marginally increase the utilisation of the runways. There is a program under way to update radar installations, which will also make a contribution. We will see also with the introduction of the new system of landing movement charges from 1 July a consequential action, I believe, by those lesser airlines to better utilise their aircraft. They will be paying on a user pays basis each time they use Mascot; they will be paying a charge for each movement.

Going on to the next matter, the point that the honourable member overlooked in his question is that the Committee also made a recommendation that intra-state airlines should use a wider range of more modern aircraft with 30 to 36 seats and aircraft with fewer than 18 seats should be discouraged. That is fundamental to the utilisation of Mascot airport. The problem at Mascot airport is not a problem of utilisation by the airlines. In fact, if one compares the figures for 1985 with those for 1975, one finds that the international airlines, the major domestic trunk airlines and the regional airlines with the larger aircraft were using Mascot about as often, and in some cases even less often, in 1985 than they were using it in 1975. The problem at Mascot is one of small aircraft, commuter aircraft, aircraft of a lesser size, to which Mr Riley and his team have referred and which ought to be discouraged from using the Sydney Airport. It is very interesting that Mr Riley, the former Managing Director of East-West Airlines Ltd, has seen it pertinent to make that recommendation. He knows very well the problem of small aircraft utilising Mascot. That problem will not be solved in the short term by just throwing more money at Mascot.

Overall, the policy that this Government is following to reduce congestion and to make better usage of the strip will, I believe, produce value for money for the Australian taxpayer. If the recommendations in respect of hubbing and spoking, as suggested in Press reports, are followed in New South Wales, that will reduce the number of aircraft movements and provide better services for people in country New South Wales. Certainly, it shows that throwing money at airports, building monuments for politicians, does not produce the result that taxpayers want to see; nor does it produce the kinds of results that aircraft operators themselves want to see, because of the added costs which are entailed but which cannot be justly serviced by the amount of utilisation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Treasurer. In doing so, I wish to quote a couple of paragraphs from the monthly summary of the National Australia Bank Limited:

QUESTION.PARA: It concedes that the Prices and Incomes Accord has achieved some success in reducing the growth of nominal labour costs . . .
That summary goes on to say:

The main risk is that exchange rate fluctuations will be reflected in wage levels, producing little if any economic benefit from the depreciation of the $A. A reduction in real wages is needed if the economy is to respond appropriately to the deterioration in Australia's terms of trade.
Will the Treasurer comment on these claims by the National Australia Bank in its summary?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the report, but it would be consistent with some views being put by commentators. Let me just make the point, as I have in the House on a number of occasions in the last week, that the comparative wage outcomes in this country are now exceedingly good compared with our history through the 1970s. When one looks at the table showing the latest annual comparative wage changes in countries such as the United States of America with 2.7, Japan with 4, Canada with 4.4, Australia with 6, France with 6, the United Kingdom with 7.5, Italy with 9.5 and New Zealand with 12, one sees that we are in the bottom end of that league table. I think that is the new element in Australia's competitiveness, other than, of course, the change in the exchange rate.

ANSWER.PARA: I mention also that the Government has instituted the discounting arrangements with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which will now be part and parcel of the Commonwealth's case before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in line with the renegotiation of the prices and incomes accord. The effect of that will be, of course, to discount the current wage case to give due and appropriate account of the inflationary influences released by the sudden and substantial depreciation which we have currently enhanced. From the Government's point of view, it thinks that any policy corrections which needed to be undertaken were substantially undertaken by slowing domestic demand in the economy in the latter part of 1985, by the use of monetary policy. Of course, that monetary policy is still having an influence on demand on activity and, therefore, the current account. In the meantime, as endogenous imports continue to fall, I think we are seeing the effect of the depreciation upon the whole question of net exports in this country. Hence, in my view, any prescriptions of the kinds which are offered in the journal referred to are not necessary. However, I do welcome a reference in that journal to Australia's wage outcomes which are, as I say, amongst the most competitive in the world.

The Treasurer is nodding to indicate that this was the claim that he was making against me, so therefore the House must hear me out on my refutation of that claim. The Treasurer selectively referred to the 1981-82 figure of 6 per cent but he dishonestly omitted the 1982-83 figure of 4 per cent--
—Order! I discussed this matter with the Leader of the Opposition on Friday. He must show where he personally has been misrepresented, not where the previous Government has been misrepresented.
—I am sorry, but the Treasurer specifically referred to my position as Treasurer in the former Government, and he personally identified me.

—Previous Speakers in this House-I have looked at their decisions on these matters-have laid down a pattern to be followed in the matter of personal explanations. I will not allow the House to get into a debate in which honourable members are rebutting claims that others have made. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) recognised this on Friday and I was pleased to have his support. On that occasion he pointed out that such matters constituted a debate, not a personal explanation. If honourable members will cast their minds back to last year they will remember that this situation often occurred. I shall read to the House exactly what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said about this last Friday. This is the extract from Hansard:

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr N.A. Brown

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Speaker: This is all very interesting and very enlightening but it is not a matter for the exchange of comment; it is a matter for personal explanation, and this is not one.

INTERJECT.PARA: He was referring to the Treasurer when he answered the Leader of the Opposition on that occasion. I will not allow personal explanation time to be used to make debating points for the Opposition and then the Government and so on. If the Leader of the Opposition can convince the House that he has been personally misrepresented, he may go ahead; but he may not start arguing about who said who was right and who was wrong.

I say with all due respect that the reason this circumstance is a little different from other circumstances is that in his answer to a question, the Treasurer specifically referred to me as distinct from the general policies of the Fraser Government.
—In that case the honourable member may proceed. Please be succinct.

—I am not asking for a withdrawal; I am just giving some advice.

—I have told the Leader of the Opposition that I will hear his personal explanation as he claims that he has been personally misrepresented as Treasurer. However, I hope the House takes note of the fact that we are not going to have a personal explanation turned into a debating point. I ask the Leader of the Opposition please to continue succinctly.

—I would, if I were free of the frivolous interruptions of the Deputy Government Whip. The average of the current account deficit of the Fraser years was 3.7 per cent of gross domestic product and during the Hawke Government 5 per cent. I said that the deterioration in external conditions brought about by the former Government's absence of a wage policy and the general cast of policy produced a current account deficit of 6 per cent of gross domestic product in 1981-82, which is the record. I referred to the figure for the following year of 3.9 per cent. I said that, in the context of negative growth, the only reason that it was down from 6 per cent was the recession. —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that `the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum'.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Ewen Cameron,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Griffiths and Mr McArthur.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag

Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned are deeply concerned that under the guise of ceasefire the Government of Sri Lanka has largely militarised Tamil regions and has now resorted to airship attacks in highly populated areas and indiscriminate killings of civilians which is seen even by the Indian Foreign Minister as having genocidal tendencies.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call upon the Government to:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: One would think that more than 40 years after the end of the Second World War there would be little left to uncover about the roles of major individuals and governments in that war. After World War II millions of displaced persons, refugees and other migrants came to Australia from nations which were the remnants of Europe. Many of these were Serbians, many were Croatians and again, the vast majority of both these groups were either victims of the nazis and their occupation or active anti-nazi fighters. These people were welcomed in Australia and their subsequent contribution to this country is highly valued.

However it is also obvious that there were also a number of people from various wartime occupied countries who took part in premeditated atrocities against their fellow human beings. These people are obviously a minority and through their wartime activities and continuing activities in Australia-and that is the most important point; they continue these activities-they bring discredit to the remainder of the peace-loving and blameless members of their own ethnic community. Let there be no claim or insinuation throughout this debate or subsequently that this matter implies in any way a collective guilt of these ethnic communities. This matter is aimed solely at the individuals responsible.

It is of deep concern to me that evidence now being made public strongly suggests that there was a massive conspiracy by successive Liberal governments throughout the 1950s and 1960s to allow war criminals entry into Australia, to protect them once they arrived and to give them political asylum in this country for as long as they wished to remain. The Liberal Party, particularly in New South Wales, has given succour and support to a number of war criminals purely on the basis that they were useful for mobilising voting power among their ethnic communities in Australia. Right at the time when Liberal Ministers were denying in the Parliament and to the Australian people that war criminals and collaborators had entered Australia, ASIO, British and American documents prove that this was a blatant lie.

The Liberal Party today continues to protect a number of persons who have nazi collaborationist backgrounds. The example of Lyenko Urbanchich is well known, but this is just the tip of the iceberg. The case of Srecko Rover, a resident of Melbourne, is a glaring example of how the Australian Government not only allowed the entry of nazi war criminals and collaborators but also, through ASIO, monitored their continued and often criminal political activities without moving to stop them. This was despite repeated assurances inside and outside Parliament that immigration screening procedures were, according to the then Immigration Minister, Mr Holt: `In every instance . . . thorough and efficient'. Documents gained from British and United States military and intelligence sources indicate that during the three years after the war those governments had embarked upon what they cynically called `Operation Doublecross'. This plan to subvert Yugoslavian aims of bringing quisling collaborators and war criminals to trial was a most extraordinary denial of justice. It is clear, from Australian security documents that the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) has sought to table, that the Australian Government did likewise by allowing the entry of a number of well-known war criminals.

Srecko Rover, alias Josip Kovacevic, was one such person. Immediately after the independent state of Croatia was formed in 1941, Rover became a member of the Ustashi police force whose speciality was persecution of members of opposition parties. According to the official newspaper Narodni Novine, dated 14 July 1941, he was then appointed to the notorious murderous mobile court martial in Sarajevo. He must have learned well because two years later he returned to Zagreb to become a commander of a unit in the Poglavnik's bodyguard, the elite unit of Ante Pavelic. United States documents make clear that any member of this organisation was ineligible for refugee status and faced a prima facie case for a war crimes trial. In 1944 Rover was decorated with the Silver Medal of the Poglavnik Ante Pavelic for courage. Bands of Ustashi roamed the countryside with knives, bludgeons and machine guns slaying men, women and little children, desecrating Serbian churches . . . killing became a cult, an obsession . . . even their German and Italian allies were dismayed at their excesses.

Upon fleeing Yugoslavia in 1946, Rover and another former Ustashi officer, Jilk Drago, joined with others to organise terrorist groups in Italy and Austria. TALK.START.PARA: —The Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill 1986 will transfer the responsibility for the collection of the $20 airport departure tax from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to the international airlines from 1 July. Departure tax is estimated to generate $48.5m in this financial year at a direct cost of about $1m and an additional indirect cost of up to half a million dollars. This $48.5m will be considered attributable revenue for the purpose of cost recovery against the cost of running the Department of Aviation. I will refer again to cost recovery in this context.

SPEECH.PARA: The current situation is that the departure tax stamps are sold from booths and elsewhere-I refer particularly to those sold from booths-on behalf of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. On 31 May last year, I received a reply from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) concerning the provision of departure tax stamps. He stated:

32 staff are employed by my Department in the collection of departure tax. They sell about 87% of stamps at airport booths. Stamps are also sold from all offices of my Department, passport offices (Department of Foreign Affairs), by Australia Post (Pt Hedland) and by some customs officers in remote localities.
Annual salary and overtime costs are about $813,000. In addition, the following items of expenditure are associated with the collection of departure tax:
payments to Australia Post for storage of bulk stocks of departure tax and exempt stamps around Australia-$27,000 in 1984-85,
payments of commission to Australia Post for sale issue of departure tax and exempt stamps at Cairns (until 1 March 1985) and Pt Hedland-$37,000 in 1984-85,
printing of stamps and freight to Australia Post distribution outlets-$22,000 in 1984-85,
payments to credit card companies for commission. This arrangement was introduced in December 1984 and is expected to cost $100,000 in a full year.
Departure tax raised-$46.9m in 1984-85.

In answer to a further question that I put to the Minister, he replied that over 100 countries levy some form of tax at the point of departure and the most comparable taxes are collected in Hong Kong, New Zealand, the Philippines and Singapore. In answer to another question, he replied:

Enquiries made of 11 countries (whose airlines operate in and out of Australia and which comprise 46.6% of market traffic) revealed that, of those countries, 5 of them have departure tax collected by government employees (Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, Indonesia and Thailand) and in 5 by airlines employees, (United Kingdom, United States of America, Canada, New Zealand and Malaysia). In one country (Philippines) the tax is collected by both government and airline employees.

That was the situation as at 31 May last year. Of course, it is still the situation until 1 July. It raises two points in passing that are of considerable interest. One is the fact of Australia Post's involvement under the current arrangements. This will become more significant later in the debate. The second matter of interest is the credit card arrangements and what will be the position regarding any new arrangements. In regard to the Budget statements of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) issued on 20 August last year, statement No. 4 of Budget Paper No. 1 reads:

The Government has decided to discontinue the current method of collecting the $20 flat rate of Departure Tax in favour of a ticket tax falling on passengers ticketing in Australia only. A range of options is currently being examined. The new proposal is predicated on maintaining existing revenue levels (estimated to be $48.5m in 1985-86) and produce administrative savings.

That, of course, was to commence on 1 January. The Government subsequently decided that it was unworkable or that it was not a growth tax and announced in November that it would revert to the $20 tax and transfer the responsibility for collection to the airlines. This abrupt turnaround from the Budget announcement caused confusion and consternation in both the travel industry and the airline industry. Tour operators complained that total cost contractual arrangements for overseas visitors excluded a tax as from 1 January. They claimed that this would cost them thousands of dollars. The Australian Tourism Industry Association justifiably attacked the Government over the sudden reversal of policy and also questioned whether the $20 was to be indexed. My colleague the shadow Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), will talk further about this.

The airlines were even more unhappy with this sudden and equally off-the-cuff example of government decision making. The international airlines and their agents, to their credit, although naturally unhappy with the government proposal, agreed to the procedure from 1 July, provided they were allowed to use the existing collection booths at the terminals; they were assisted in transferring as much of the sale of the stamps as possible to off-airport venues, particularly the post office; the Government retained control of the provision of exemption stamps; and accounts system was established so that payment would be made within a 60-day period after the sale of the stamps; and, generally, the airlines be allowed to collect the tax in the most efficient manner as they determined, Unfortunately, few, if any, of these points have been resolved at this stage. This reaffirms the unplanned nature of the whole government operation. Further discussions will be held, I understand, next week. Time is running out to have the arrangements and the regulations in place by 1 July. The result is evident in this incomplete Bill, relying almost completely on regulations for implementation and administration.

The Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) has stated that the airlines will only have their special booths at the international terminals until 1 October. These booths, as I said earlier, are used at present by Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs personnel. The Minister has also claimed that these booths cause congestion in the terminals. The airlines deny that the booths have ever caused congestion in the terminals and point to the other reasons for congestion in terminals, particularly the international terminal at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. It is the congestion at the Kingsford-Smith terminal which at present is giving us such a bad name internationally. That is caused by problems with the overall design of the departure floor and the number and allocation of check-in counters at that terminal. The Minister's intransigence on this issue will only increase congestion in the all-important check-in counter area, because the requirement that he is forcing or appears to be forcing at this stage on the airlines will add to the congestion in that already congested area.

The airlines estimate that up to $30,000 per hour is collected at the Kingsford-Smith terminal in peak times. This will require secure booths at strategic points when they have the responsibility of collecting that amount of money. This will present both logistical and personnel problems. The Kingsford-Smith congestion problem will be further compounded by the renovation program at the international terminal while these works are in progress. It will be up to three years before this renovation program is completed. Until then, I believe the Minister should allow the airlines to use the present booths; otherwise we will have congestion on congestion and confusion on confusion at critical times in that departure area.

Approximately 54 per cent of airline tickets to and from Australia are now sold outside Australia and this will increase as the weak Australian dollar makes this country a more attractive destination and overseas trips a less attractive option for Australians. The fear of terrorism and general airport security in Europe and the Mediterranean will add to our desirability as a destination for foreign tourists. The realisation of this trend in the balance of our departures and arrivals was no doubt an important aspect of the Government's removal of the $40 tax of Australians only, because Government revenue must be maintained and increased at all costs. That is very much the order of the day for this Government.

This percentage-the 54 per cent-is also important in relation to the efficient sale of departure tax stamps and congestion at the terminals. As the majority of tickets are purchased by foreigners overseas, they will not be familiar with the Australian situation and will naturally use the departure terminal to purchase the stamps and, in some cases, to even learn of its existence. The significance of the airlines request for the use already made of the post office to be made universal for the sale of such stamps become apparent and sensible. The post office is a land mark in every community-it is expert in the provision of all kinds of stamps-the ones to put on envelopes, for tax and also for departure. However, for this to be successful, incoming tourists should be alerted by the Government to the need for a departure stamp and the ease of obtaining such a stamp at a post office. I also support the request of the airlines for the Department to deal direct with the post office and not require the airlines to do this.

Two types of exemptions to the departure tax stamps requirement are relevant to this legislation. The first has been mentioned by the Minister in his second reading speech, namely, small charter operators, private flights and aerial work, et cetera, and that the existing arrangement using Customs offices will continue, which certainly is acceptable to the Opposition. The second concerns exempt categories of passengers departing through the major terminals. The existing regulation would exempt royalty or their representatives, heads of State and government other than Australia, guests of the Commonwealth, defence personnel required to travel overseas or defence personnel of another country required to visit Australia, crews of vessels just visiting Australia, and Department of Aviation employees required on an aircraft going overseas in relation to their duties and, finally, repatriated migrants.

As I understand the legislation-I am quite happy to be corrected by the Minister if I am wrong-the Minister is also attempting to force airline employees at the counters and booths to determine this latter form of exemption eligibility. I believe that that is an unfair imposition on those employees. My only personal experience in this matter has been at Hong Kong where there is a special booth determining exemption eligibility. The same should be followed here and I believe it should be staffed by people who do represent the Government because it is the Government that determines what are the exemption categories. The Government will be using the airlines as tax collectors and saving up to $1.5m collection costs, which raises several important principles, the first being that, because it will be indirect revenue to the Government, it should also be included in aviation cost recovery. I ask the Minister to seriously consider that.

The Minister has already stated that the revenue collected from the departure tax stamps, that is, the $48.5m estimated for this year, will be part of attributable cost recovery. I acknowledge and commend the Minister for that. However, I believe that the $1.5m the Government saves by making the airlines tax collectors on its behalf should also become part of attributable cost recovery and I ask the Minister, both in sincerity and from a common sense viewpoint, to consider that point. Secondly, the airlines should not be required to pay for the tax stamps on receipt of such stamps from the Government but by an account arrangement which, in general terms, would mean payment up to 60 days after the sale of those stamps for the money to be transferred to the Government. The third point is that to be helpful and flexible in the requirements for the collection; that is, for the Government to be helpful and flexible in the requirements for the collection, so that the airlines can do it economically and efficiently with as little disruption as possible to the departing passengers.

The recent delays and confusion by the strike of the Department of Immigration employees who sell the stamps has been firmly and rightly condemned by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hurford. He pointed out the damage that this selfish action was doing to our international image. The best way to reduce the likelihood of further strikes and the impact of any further strike action and to repair our overseas image is for the Minister to state clearly and firmly now that if such action occurs again departing passengers will be automatically exempted from the requirements to obtain a stamp. That is not a fanciful suggestion because, in simply looking at some of the newspapers of late last week, there are still hints and threats of further industrial action by those Department of Immigration employees. By one clear statement the Minister can resolve that issue for the future by saying: `If you go on strike you will not achieve anything because the departing passengers will have automatic right to leave Australia without the requirement of a stamp'. I believe that that is the sort of statement and action that is needed to ensure that our international image is not further damaged by such stupid action and also, of course, it will reduce the likelihood of such action occurring.

The departure tax was last increased in 1981 to $20. It was $10 from the time of introduction in 1978 until 1981 and it can be claimed that its real cost has been subsequently reduced by inflation. However, it remains one of the highest, if not the highest, departure tax in the world and the Minister has stated in reply to a question from me in the Parliament earlier this year that it will not be indexed. In a 15 December media release he also stated:
The Government has no intention of escalating the amount they would have to pay in departure tax.

It was referring to departing Australians. Those two statements are encouraging as it would appear that the Government is either not going to index or increase by some other means the cost of the departure tax stamps. However, it does not prevent the Government from increasing the tax in the Budget to, say, $30 and, in fact, there are rumours circulating that this will be done. If that does happen, in light of earlier comments by the Minister, any increase would be seen as the Minister breaking his word. I am sure that the Minister would not like that to be said.

Furthermore, I believe it would be absurd and would cause considerable confusion on top of the problems there already will be in the implementation of the tax from 1 July if any increase were to happen so soon after those new administrative arrangements had commenced and were still being implemented. So, I suggest to the Minister, if he is able to say today in closing the debate quite firmly and clearly that the $20 level will not be increased for either the rest of this financial year and next financial year, that will allow the implementation to be far smoother than the confusion that could occur with an increase occurring and all the new stamps and that sort of thing required so soon after its commencement, and also would assist our tourist image overseas because, as I said earlier, we already have if not the highest one of the highest departure taxes in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our image overseas could not be better.
—Has the Minister thought of Indonesia lately?
—What about their image here?

—I am responding to the Minister's comment and he would be wise not to make any more comments in response to that answer. I call on the Minister to unequivocally state-I am going to do this now simply because of the interjection so that we can see what the position is after the Budget-that there will not be any increase in the Budget or anything that will mean an increase in the cost of the stamp until at least the end of the next financial year. I ask the Minister to indicate when these departure tax regulations will be issued and also the cost recovery regulations for the aviation industry. These latter regulations are relevant to the tax and are of great concern to the whole aviation industry, particularly general aviation. I also ask the Minister to reveal a greater flexibility and degree of co-operation than has hitherto been shown in his negotiations with the airlines and agree to their major requests.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not oppose the legislation, because of the generous co-operation of the international airlines and assures them that on return to government we will be prepared to review the administrative arrangements. We will also closely inspect the regulations and discuss their impact with the airline representatives. Finally, I congratulate the airlines on their most constructive and co-operative response to this Government imposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation before us today, like all of the legislation brought forward by this Government, deals with common sense. In essence we are taking away the responsibility for collecting this departure tax from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and handing it over in such a way that it can be easily identifiable with the airline industry. It enhances the Government's policy of cost recovery within the industry. Further measures to be brought in by the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) will give more effect to that policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition spokesman on aviation, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), spoke about the way in which airlines may collect this tax, but that certainly is a decision that is up to the airlines themselves. The Government really would not want to interfere in that any more than it had to. The Opposition spokesman also spoke about practices in other countries. I can remember last year when I was invited to the United States of America by the United States Government. I was given my ticket in Australia. The United States departure tax was paid and collected in Australia on behalf of the airline here to be handed over to the United States Government. I cannot see any reason why airlines in other countries cannot reciprocate by collecting tax in their countries to be paid over to the Australian Government in exactly the same way as I have just detailed.

One of the better parts of this legislation is that upon arriving at the airport there will be one less obstacle for departing passengers. Many of us in the House know from personal experience that when a person gets to an international airport and is going overseas the last thing he should be doing is running around trying to get a stamp to put on the front of the ticket. A long queue can lead to frustration. Those passengers who are unaware of departure tax regulations in Australia get to the Customs barrier only to be turned back. That must be very daunting. Not only that, many of our overseas visitors have already cashed in all their Australian currency. They then find that they have to cash in another traveller's cheque if they can in order to get Australian currency to get the tax stamp to put on their ticket. So from a convenience point of view I believe that the departure of international travellers will be enhanced by this legislation.

The Opposition spokesman also read out some of the exempt passengers. In the list I have here there are 20 different categories. In reading the categories I think there is very little scope for any confusion as to which categories someone would fit in. The list includes passengers under the age of 12 years who are detailed on passports; crew members; diplomatic and consular representatives travelling on diplomatic passports-they would be quite easy to identify; persons who do not disembark in Australia; United States and Papua New Guinea military personnel; persons being extradited or deported-they would be known by the handcuff on their left wrist; members of the British royal family, most of whom are well known from Press clippings; the Governor-General and spouse, State governors and spouses-we extend every other privilege to them, so why not this one; heads of state and governments; persons visiting Australia at Commonwealth invitation; migrants being repatriated or immigrating elsewhere at Commonwealth expense; persons departing Australia within 24 hours of arrival; and, finally, the Australian Aborigines and Papua New Guinea citizens moving across the Torres Straits. There is more than something a little symbolic in the fact that they are No. 20. Certainly, apart from the categories listed, I do not think that there is any reason why anybody could claim that he would not have to pay the departure tax, but in the unlikely event that there may be some dispute, I reject--

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been disputes-3,000 people have been held up.

—There may be a few disputes around the place, but certainly having someone at a special booth 24 hours a day at our eight different international terminals should be something that the Waste Watch Committee, set up by the members of the Opposition, should look at. Here they are advocating it. What a silly thing to advocate. Opposition members want somebody sitting in a booth to hear somebody's complaint. Can honourable members imagine a stack of departing passengers at that special booth trying to get out of Australia and the poor old harassed public servant has to decide on the spot whether the $20 should be paid. I put it to honourable members that it would be a much better way to handle it in the way the Minister has said it should be handled.
—What about the bureaucrats?

—As the honourable member for Perth points out, it is absolutely amazing that the members of the Opposition are saying that they want more bureaucrats. I think that matter should be referred to the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee. If any shadow Minister ever refers it to the Committee he will be thrown off the front bench for ever advocating such a policy. What the Minister says is quite right, passengers should pay the tax. They can then write us a letter. We will have a look at their case and, if they are right, we will refund it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition spokesman also spoke about the cost in comparison with other countries. Two of the prime destinations for Australians are New Zealand and Hong Kong. In both cases the departure tax exceeds ours. It is $40 in New Zealand, which at the time, amounted to $A31.50. In Hong Kong a person pays $HK120, which is around $A21.24. Honourable members can see that our departure tax, even though it may be high in comparison with some countries, is quite reasonable in comparison with other countries.

I turn now to some departure tax statistics. I will just dwell on the number of passengers because as the Opposition spokesman has pointed out, not only has the cost of the departure tax increased from $10 to $20, but there was also a move to bring the age of children down from 18 to 12 years. So just looking at the revenue does not always tell the full picture. The number of passengers coming into this country was 2,068,000 in 1981-82. The following year we did not do much better-there was an increase of only 0.4 per cent from that figure to 2,075,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of the Opposition didn't know anything about tourism.

—They didn't know anything about tourism, as the honourable member for Perth has pointed out. They had a goldmine as the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) points out, and they did not know what to do with it. That is reflected in the figures. Between 1981-82 and 1982-83 there was in increase of 0.4 of a per cent. What a miser- able percentage. The rest of the world must have laughed at us for not taking tourism seriously. Between 1982-83 and 1983-84 tourism started to pick up because of the influence this Government had on tourism, and there was a staggering 5.3 per cent increase compared to 0.4 per cent the year before. So in percentage terms it went up by approximately-what is my maths like?-1200 per cent.
—Pretty poor so far.

—It was a lot better than the mathematics of those opposite. They could increase tourism by only 0.4 per cent in their last year and we increased it by 5.3 per cent, which is over 1200 per cent in one year. In 1983-84 there were 2,186,000 passengers. But the following year, 1984-85-by this time the Paul Hogan advertisements had started taking effect in America-there was a staggering increase of 10.9 per cent. This Government actually doubled the figure from the year before. So tourism increased by 1200 per cent and a further 200 per cent on top of that. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen), who is at the table, showed us an excellent movie last Wednesday night-Crocodile Dundee. I am sure that when that hits the studios in America we will not be able to hold the Americans back. Even though we have estimated only a modest 7 per cent increase, once the Americans see Paul Hogan in Crocodile Dundee we will not have enough planes to bring them in. Honourable senators talked about increasing the tax on departure stamps from $20 to $30. That is what the Opposition might have done if it wanted to raise revenue. The only way to increase something is to put the cost up. This Government is bringing more people into the country. That is another way of collecting tax. That is what we have been doing. In 1985-86, we have estimated we will exceed 2,500,000 passenger departures from Australia. That is up 7 per cent projected. For 1986-87 we have again projected a modest 7 per cent increase. Wait until Crocodile Dundee hits the theatres in the United States-we will not be able to keep the Americans away.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spoken on the Bill long enough, and I know that the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) has many worthwhile things to say about the Bill. I notice the Opposition spokesman on tourism coming to the dispatch box. This Government has done everything that it can not only to promote tourism overseas but, by the legislation we are debating today, to look after the tourists when they come here and to make sure that they will not be fumbling in their pockets for their last $20 to get out of the country. We hope that the airlines will take into account the Government's wishes and build the cost of this tax into their tickets, as is done in the United States of America.

Finally, I congratulate the Minister for Avi- ation on the excellent way he has handled this portfolio. I am sure that we have seen the start of many worthwhile reforms. There are two Ministers at the table, and I have said something nice about both of them. There is no worry about me getting into favour with these two Ministers. Certainly the Minister for Aviation has done everything right to ensure that everything that can be done within the airline industry is done to make visits by our overseas visitors most enjoyable. Getting rid of these tax collection booths and ensuring that we do not have appeal booths, which were advocated by the Opposition, will make the stay of tourists in Australia that much more pleasurable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I applaud the new-found enthusiasm for tourism of the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) and his support of the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris), who is at the table. I can only say that I hope that, whatever other abilities the Minister brings to his portfolio, it is not the same lack of ability that he brings to the messy affair of departure tax in this country. It is interesting that the Government now supports the proposition that the departure tax should be collected by the airlines themselves, because in 1981 the Labor Party was vehemently opposed to such a move. I note with some interest also that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, (Mr John Brown), who was then the shadow Minister, was most outstanding in his opposition to this move. I quote from Hansard of 26 August 1981 when the honourable member was on his feet speaking:

SPEECH.PARA: What is the point in Australians leaving Australia having to pay this tax? No one can convince me that a Japanese tourist who comes to Australia and finds he has to pay another $10 to go home will consider that a great attraction. The Government can in no way justify the imposition of this tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said this?
—Mr John Brown said this, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. In 1981 he was in full flight. I repeat what he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government-
that was us at the time, of course-
can in no way justify the imposition of this tax. We will oppose it vehemently.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what I said when I was shadow Minister.

—I am not sure what the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment said at that time. He might like to tell us during the debate. I presume that what the Minister is saying now is that he is opposed to what the now Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism said in 1981. The wheel has now turned full circle-and that is a good thing-but it is interesting to look back to see what the present Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism said at that time. I might say that he is the same Minister who has been under some criticism in the last week. He is the Minister who hires consultants at government expense and lets them wander round the country for months on end. At one stage the Minister said that the consultant was lost for a month and he did not know where he was. I presume they could find him to give him his pay cheque during that month, and I presume that when he came back he was grilled about what he had actually been doing during that time.
—Who was this consultant?
—Mr Groux, consultant to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. Mr Groux went absent without leave for a month. No one knew where he was and what he was supposed to be doing.

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I am a very reasonable Minister, as you heard early this afternoon. These debates are usually of a reasonably wide-ranging nature, but on this occasion I think the shadow Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism should be directed to address the Bill, which is a fairly narrow and mechanical Bill dealing simply with the mechanics of the collection of a tax which does have pertinence for tourism. Mr Deputy Speaker, I would be grateful if you would direct the honourable member to direct his remarks to the contents of the Bill.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I acknowledge the point the Minister is making.
—I think the honourable member for McPherson should be allowed time to round off his remarks, which will enable him to get back to the Bill while he has established the link.

—The point I make is that we are talking here about departure tax. Departure tax is very important in the creation of a tourist industry in this country. The last real contact tourists have with Australia is when they go and pay their $20. How they pay it and how they are relieved of it is a very important part of the tourist industry because, as I will come to a bit later, the other day in Sydney 3,000 visitors were hammering on doors trying to pay their departure tax. Probably half of those people, on average, would have been tourists in this country. If half of them were tourists, that is 1,500 people. I think it is very doubtful whether those 1,500 tourists will ever come back to Australia again, seeing they were subjected to that. That is a direct reflection on the tourist industry and a reflection on the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism because I have not heard him say a word about this important issue. It is because of the conduct of his portfolio and his lack of attention to this matter that I raise a couple of other matters in connection with the administration of the Minister's portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: I can see by the look on your face, Mr Deputy Speaker, that you are not convinced that that tenuous argument has any bearing on what I have just been saying, so I will not persist except to say in conclusion on this section of the debate that if the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism took a bit more interest in the departure tax problem that has been raised in this country perhaps our tourism industry would continue to grow and prosper at a greater rate than it has. I would also say that, if that is indicative of the attention the Minister pays to his portfolio, it is backed up by the sorts of people he hires as consultants in his portfolio who are allowed to wander at will around this country on the government payroll. The Minister said: `Well, he was adrift for a month. No one knew where he was'. Of course, we will hear more about Mr Groux because if the Minister will not tell us what Mr Groux was doing for that month, where he was paid and how much he was paid--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I think you are fairly tolerant with the shadow Minister. He is now getting right off the track and I suggest that you draw him back to the Bill.
—The honourable member for McPherson has made a connection and I think he made it validly. The honourable member has also made the point that he will move on, and I will allow him to continue.

—Thank you for your indulgence and patience, Mr Deputy Speaker. I believe it was an important point to make about the conduct of that particular portfolio. I turn now to the narrow aspects of this Bill, the departure tax. We are not opposed to the outline and the general objectives which the Minister has indicated, but the handling of this transfer has been going on for a long time and it has been an extremely messy affair. I refer to the initial lack of consultation with the airlines. Then we had a proposal, at one stage floated through the Press, that the departure tax was to be put up to $40. That was denied. Then the tax was to be a percentage of the air fare. God knows how much that was going to cost us. Then the tax was back to $20. Then we were going to maintain the booths in the airports, then we were going to abolish the booths. Then the starting date was to be 1 January 1986; then it was to be 1 July 1986. I am interested to know-I presume that the Minister will tell us-whether that is still the starting date. We want to know what the situation is because the next Budget will come around before we actually get on to collecting this tax. I believe that the Minister should be letting the airlines get on with it without constantly arguing about how they will do it.

SPEECH.PARA: The other question I wish to raise in connection with the departure tax-a tax which amounts to some $50m a year; it is not peanuts-is why some of it is not used to improve facilities at our airports. If that were done the Government would get more support from the Opposition and certainly from the airlines. In Brisbane we have no international terminal in sight, although we are to have an international airport as such. Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, as the Minister must realise, is becoming notorious not only in Australia but also throughout the world for its bad facilities and its congestion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The best city in the world.

—I am talking about Sydney Airport. I went to Sydney the other day to look at the airport and I must say that I was appalled. It is the main gateway to Australia. As I understand it, the Government is to spend $20m on Sydney Airport, but the program has not yet been approved. It will be spread over three years. It is obvious that by the time that $20m is spent it will be too little, too late. A total of $20m for what is required at Sydney Airport is a relatively small amount. The reception arrangements for overseas visitors at Sydney Airport are abysmal. Incoming visitors have to wait for hours at peak periods. I am told that it is doubtful whether the improvements that are proposed will achieve the objective. Again, this situation reflects on the only growth industry that we have in this country, that is, the tourist industry. The tourist industry is going to grow and grow.
—Thanks to the best promotional campaign in Australia's history.

—It is not due to the efforts of the Government. It is due basically, as the Minister well knows, to the devaluation of the dollar and the uncertainties in other places in the world because of terrorism. They are the two issues that are increasing tourism.
—That is part of it.

—Whatever the Minister says, the fact is that tourism in this country will grow enormously. What we should be doing in a bipartisan way is making sure that visitors are received and dispatched in some degree of comfort. That is what we are talking about.
—Be gracious and give the Minister some credit for a brilliant campaign.

—I have said many times that the Minister deserves a lot of credit for what he has done, but the fact is that tourism in this country will grow, basically because of devaluation and the uncertainties in other countries.
