If we agree that tourism will grow, should we not be looking at making sure that the facilities for the reception and dispatch of our tourists are adequate? If we treat the tourists as we treated those 1,500 tourists who were hammering on the door to get out, they will not come back. Tourism is the only growth industry we have; and it is the industry that we should be looking after particularly. We should not, as the Government has done, allow a few ticket collectors at the Sydney office to make up their own minds as to whether they will sell tickets to people going out of this country. What sort of a government is it that lets a few public servants dictate to it as to whether they are going to sell tickets? The matter is not over yet.
—What would you have done?

—No work, no pay; that is the first thing that would be done. Secondly, Sydney Airport and all other airports are the best possible example of the need for flexibility in industrial relations in order to have people at the airports in the peak periods. Permanent part time work is what is required, Customs officers and health and immigration officials should be at the airports at the time they are required and we should not have a lot of people standing around when they are not required. The ticket collectors will not tell us whether they will take industrial action. Pending a meeting with the Federal Government, a spokesman for the ticket collectors said:

SPEECH.PARA: We do not plan to give any warning of further industrial actions, it is not for public knowledge nor do we want management to know our plans so that they can fill in our job.

The Government puts up with that sort of rubbish from public servants over whom it should have reasonable control and who are doing great damage to tourists who are leaving this country. Obviously, those tourists will not come back. I suggest that one of the things the Government should do, apart from implementing the physical improvements that are required to the airport structures, is look very closely at introducing permanent part time work at the airports so that our very important visitors and returning Australians are not held up for hours at our airports waiting for public services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) has canvassed the vast majority of issues involved in respect of the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill, but there are some things that I would like to say. While the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) gave what I think was a fair exposition of how the tax operates and its history, he mentioned that he believed that Australia Post should play a part in the distribution of departure tax stamps. I must say that I find that a rather bizarre prospect. Indeed, he said that he would give us some information on credit card facilities, yet he never got to that exposition. He suggested that this change to the departure tax arrangements would increase congestion at terminals and that logistics and personnel problems would increase as a result. Further, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) said that the recent problem at Sydney Airport, where 3,000 people were unable to obtain departure tax stamps, would be exacerbated by this legislation. I find it very difficult to follow the logic of that. Surely, if tickets and stamps are made available at the airline check-in counters and if planes are flying, one would be able to get departure tax stamps. Certainly that runs contrary to the logic espoused by the Opposition in suggesting that that problem would become worse if the booths were removed.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point raised by the honourable member for McPherson related to airport expenditure and the congestion and difficulties that exist at various airports. That is something to which I would like to come back later. Anybody who has travelled overseas-the vast majority of members in this place have had the opportunity to do so-will realise that it can be an inconvenience to have to check in at an airport and then hurry around to find where one can obtain a stamp for the $20 departure tax. If the check-in and departure stamps were available at the same place, I believe that that would improve the efficiency of our airports rather than have the other effect. I recently had to backtrack in Perth for exactly this reason, whereas in Singapore and Bangkok it was possible to buy the departure tax stamp as one checked in. Certainly, that was more convenient.

This measure will also save money. I would have thought that that would be something that would bring delight to the hearts of members of the Opposition, yet they seem to want to employ more bureaucrats and are suggesting that privatisation of this procedure is something to which they would be opposed. As my colleague the honourable member for Canning suggested, United States airlines are already collecting tax for the United States Government here in Australia. It seems a much more efficient way to collect tax in these circumstances. Of course, the airlines bear the cost of collection, just as the banks bear the costs of collecting the bank account debits tax and the costs of sales tax collection are the responsibility not of government but of those who are liable for it.

Another point that has been made by the Opposition related to its concern that this tax may in fact be indexed. It is interesting to note that in 1981 when it was last increased from $10 to $20 it was regarded as a much more significant tax than it is now. It has stayed at that level since 1981. I suppose its present value could be regarded as being about half of its value when it was introduced in 1981. So the Opposition with its concern that the tax would be indexed, seems to be shedding crocodile tears, because surely, if the tax is increased by indexation, its value will still be much lower than it was when it was introduced by the Opposition.

Members of the Opposition also talked about difficulties that exist with exemptions. I point out that more than 70 per cent of the exemptions are for passengers who are under 12. I imagine that there would be no difficulty at an airline counter in ascertaining the age of a likely traveller, particularly a young traveller, who would have a passport. So some of the concerns that members of the Opposition have expressed do not bear consideration.

This change in the collection of departure tax will certainly increase the efficiency with which airlines are able to function and with which passengers can be passed through our airports. I wish to finish on this point because it is of some concern to the constituents of Perth that our existing airport was designed 25 years ago for the Commonwealth Games held in 1962, and it was then a new and modern building. Since then there has been a significant increase of about 20 per cent annually in overseas travel and of 10 per cent annually in domestic travel. Clearly, in that 24 years the airport has become far from sufficient and unable to handle the volume of traffic that goes through there now.

It is this Government that has embarked on building a new terminal. It is this Government that has spent over $60m to improve the facilities at the airport and to provide Western Australians with an efficient processing and handling passenger facility for the future. Although this legislation is only a small measure, I believe it will provide an improvement in the efficiency with which passengers are handled. We in Western Australia are glad that finally, after a long time, our airport facilities have been improved. This is only a small measure but it will increase the efficiency of passenger flow. It will save the Government money and it is consistent with the sort of tax that is levied in a large number of other countries. I cannot see any reason for not supporting this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) in the debate on the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill, because this will probably be one of the few times that we will agree on anything. We certainly agree on this Bill as it enjoys the support of the Opposition. Other speakers have spoken about the dramatic increase in the number of tourists coming into Australia. There is no doubt about that. If one looks at the latest aviation outlook paper, one can see that the graph showing departures and arrivals relating to international travel continues to go up. The figure this financial year is over 8 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The figures that I have been able to find show that tourism is now worth somewhere over 5 per cent of gross domestic product, which is in excess of $8 billion, and that means over 340,000 jobs are involved. Also in 1982-83-these are rather old figures-expenditure by overseas visitors exceeded $1 billion, which then equalled 66 per cent of wool exports and 84 per cent of wheat exports. There has been quite a dramatic growth since then so it is a major industry. Obviously great development is going on at the moment. That is particularly so in north Queensland and in the Northern Territory.

This tax does have some drawbacks, which the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has outlined. There are a few alternatives which could be considered and which I hope the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) will take on board as having been genuinely made. This proposal is a further imposition of government on the airlines, but, in total, I agree that it is a sensible change. The tax take is quite interesting. When this measure was first started in 1978-79, $12m was collected in that year. Last year, 1984-85 it had grown to $47m. The estimate for this year, 1985-86, is $49m. This tax, once collected, goes to Consolidated Revenue. Looking at the growth in tourism and at the need for continued growth, one could ask the question: Why cannot some of those funds be directed towards assisting the tourism industry?

Interestingly, in the marketing section of a recent edition of the Australian, there was an article headed `No funds left to exploit tourism opportunity'. The article went on to say that the funds that were used by the Australian Tourist Commission had been expended and that there were no more funds left to continue promotion. We heard a lot today about Crocodile Dundee, Koala Brown and all the other promotional activities but it seems to me that we have a unique chance in Australia to pursue the very new opportunities which, unfortunately, have arisen due to the Libyan crisis. The point needs to be be made that the Tourist Commission is short of funds, and detailed consideration ought to be given towards directing some of this massive amount of money-$49m in this financial year-towards tourism.

It is also interesting that on the same page as the article about the problems of marketing in the tourist industry we can go to the next article which was concerned over labour costs. This article has some significance with regard to some of the remarks I want to make later about the collection of the departure tax. The head of the International Hotels Corporation made an interesting observation about Australian tourism. He said:
You have one of the finest holiday destinations in the world but labour costs are making the industry outrageously expensive for operators and travellers . . .

Labour costs represent 45 per cent of our total revenue in Australia, but with most of our 99 other hotels across the world, the figure is 35 per cent-the difference representing gross profit, which I'm afraid has to be passed on to the traveller.

There we have it. I think the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), the Opposition spokesman for tourism, talked about the need for some flexibility in the labour markets and I certainly concur with those remarks. It is also interesting to go back over the debates on this issue. I noticed that one speaker referred to the comments made by the honourable member for Robertson, the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen). It would be interesting to hear him elucidate those points further, if he is able to. I do not know whether he is on the speakers list.

When this issue was debated back in September 1978 a former member in this place-I refer to the then member for Bowman, who has now reappeared as the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), and who will be speaking later in this debate-made the very point then that some of those funds ought to be directed to tourism. I hope that he will have the opportunity to expand further on that point today. The history of this tax is well known. It is interesting to go back to the report of the Bosch Committee on Aviation Cost Recovery. The Committee was set up by the Minister. Whilst the Committee made the point that this proposal was a general revenue measure, it also said:

The Committee considers, however, that because it is collected from aircraft passengers it should be considered attributable revenue for cost recovery purposes. The Committee noted that in both the U.S.A. and Canada the proceeds of taxes on departing international passengers are used for aviation cost recovery purposes. If the Government agrees to attribute departure tax collections for recovery cost purposes, the Committee recommends-
this is the important part-
that international passengers should be exempt at arrival and departure from Australia from any domestic passenger service charges which the Government-
being the Federal Government-
might also decide to introduce.

I think that the Minister deserves to be congratulated for following the first part of the Committee's recommendation, that is that those funds be seen as part of the attributable revenue for cost recovery purposes. I hope that he will keep in mind the second point made by the Committee that if any further charges are imposed, international travellers should be exempted from them. As I have said, we do not oppose this measure, but it is an impost on the airlines and it will be a cost to them. They have worked well with the Minister to bring this change about.

It is also interesting to note some of the other taxes that are being imposed on the airlines at the moment. One that has not received perhaps as much attention as it ought-although it may do so in the next few days-is the imposition of the fringe benefits tax. As I understand it, Qantas Airways Limited will have to pay somewhere in the vicinity of $8m as a result of that tax; Trans Australia Airlines, $4m; Ansett Airlines of Australia, $4m; and East-West Airlines Ltd, $500,000-odd. I wonder whether the Minister was involved in the discussions with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on those taxes, because it seems to me that two bodies under his jurisdiction will be hit with rather large sums. Perhaps he ought to have been seeking some exemptions under that fringe benefits tax at the time it was being discussed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The passengers will pay more, too.

—The passengers will pay for it, of course. Another point that I think was made by the honourable member for Murray related to the question of security at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, where $30,000 an hour is collected. That is a large amount. Recently, I went to Darwin to have a look at its airport. Obviously, it has severe security problems, and I am sure there are tax collection problems also. A further point that has to be made is that the terminal is totally inadequate. Late last week, the Minister, in answer to a question in the House, said that on his next visit to Darwin, which I think might be later this week or early next week, no decision would be made on Darwin Airport. I hope that the Minister will give that matter a high priority. All the people to whom I spoke in Darwin said that that airport was totally inadequate. Yet Darwin Airport is growing in importance. Qantas wants to put more flights through Darwin; the airport needs urgent attention. I hope that the Minister, together with the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), will find an early solution to that problem. I am sure that tourists who come into Australia through Darwin must wonder what has hit them when they see that old building with its totally inadequate facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Another thing that this Government crows about continually is the level of consultation with the unions. It talks about reaching consensus decisions. I find that rather amusing. There was an interesting article in the Australian on 25 April. It was headlined `Union threatens wildcat strikes in widening of departure tax dispute'. Four members of the Australian Public Service Association were arrested on 22 April for picketing departure tax booths in a restricted area at Sydney Airport. One wonders why the union was upset. Mr Raymond Harty of APSA claimed that it was a move by the Federal Government to `privatise a government function and cut overtime payments for 40 departure tax employees'. He then attacked the Government and went on to say:

Federal Cabinet's decision was taken unilaterally without consulting the union. The Minister for Immigration, Mr Hurford, . . . had breached the Government's policy of industrial democracy by `consistently refusing' to meet the APSA.

It was only today that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) stood up in this place and crowed about how important industrial democracy would be. He said he hoped that when the Green Paper came down people on this side of the House would treat it well and support him. I suggest to the Minister that the first thing he should do is make sure that his fellow Cabinet Ministers support industrial democracy before he comes to us and asks us for support.

Mr Harty went on to say that immigration officials had broken the law by selling tax stamps after the booths were black-banned. All I can say is that we should thank those immigration officials for breaking the law and ensuring that there were at least some sensible people in that airport to process the tourists who were waiting. It certainly left a sour taste in many people's mouths. I think that the honourable member for Murray also suggested a solution in that area, and I hope that the Minister will respond to that. It is that type of mindless union activity that concerns us on this side of the House. It was a mindless exercise of irresponsible power and that is the sort of thing that we want to see changed. That is what we have been pursuing with our industrial relations policy, about which I am sure the Government will hear more. I hope that the introduction of part time work, as suggested by the shadow Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr White), into the airport system might also alleviate those problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in speaking on the second reading of the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill. The Opposition supports this Bill with some reservations. Personally I feel that it is a great pity that we have to tax our tourists in any way. I could never understand why we found it necessary. The Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) said, in his second reading speech, that other countries tax tourists, and that is a good reason why we should do so. Obviously Australia is now well placed, as other members have mentioned, because we are in a stable part of the world and we are in a position to attract many tourists. We do not have a lot going for us in industry. We have just seen the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) doing a few flips around the globe in order to try to sell a bit more primary production but he has not had any success. However, there will continue to be an enormous growth in tourism. It creates a lot of jobs and I think it is absurd that we should tax tourists when they are leaving the country. We encourage them to come here with all sorts of advertising, to travel around the country and have a look at it and then we kick them in the backside as they are leaving. I do not see anything wrong with charging our own people some sort of tax because one might argue that it is a privilege and a luxury to travel overseas, but I think that it is absurd that we should tax tourists as they are leaving our country. In effect we say to them: `Hooray mate; you have had a good time but now we need $20 from you before you can leave Australia'.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been some suggestions that the amount should be increased to $40. I believe that the Government, in its last Budget, expressed a desire to increase this amount to $40. The trouble with these taxes is that once they are in place they are there for keeps. They are never reduced; they continually increase. It is a great pity that this should be suggested at this stage of expansion in the tourist industry. It is not that long since the departure tax was introduced. It was one of the many things that the Fraser Government did with which we do not agree too much these days. It is a great pity that this tax was ever introduced at all. Apparently in the days of the Fraser Government it was decided that there should be cost recovery in the aviation industry, and it is quite unbelievable how many public servants are now employed in that industry. I would say that there are 10 for every plane that is flying around, and that includes light aircraft.

I turn to the question of light aircraft. My electorate of Maranoa is vast-about two and a half times the size of Victoria-and light aircraft are continually needed in this part of the world. I fly around my electorate a lot. The Remuneration Tribunal has had a very detailed submission from me again this year in order to try to get unlimited charter for members who have big electorates. The Australian Labor Party believes in one vote, one value but it does not believe in allowing us to service our electorate as we should. Although the size of the electorate of Maranoa has been increased by 110,000 square kilometres, the Government has only slightly increased the air charter allowance. It is also worth noting that the cost of airline tickets has not decreased despite the sudden slump in the price of Avgas. I hope that the Minister will make a representation to Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans Australia Airlines-to Sir Peter Abeles and his mates--

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't use Avgas.

—Well, a tribunal was set up during the time of the Fraser Government to look at the cost of airline tickets. Crude oil prices have dropped substantially and although the excise has been transferred to Avgas, there has still been a slight drop in the cost of aviation fuel. It is not much, nevertheless that saving should be passed on to the travelling public. As I was saying, I believe that as parliamentarians we should be allowed unlimited charter. It is amazing that we have a credit card in our pockets, valid for both Ansett and TAA, to enable us to travel round and round this country until we get giddy, yet we cannot go to our electorates and charter aircraft in order to service those electorates properly. I point out that it is as far from my home to the western end of my electorate, which is at the Northern Territory-Birdsville corner, as it is from my home to Melbourne. That is how big my electorate is-2,000 kilometres across. The Minister is shaking his head, but I must point out that he has a Newcastle electorate. He could spit across it or walk across it before breakfast. I think he should use his influence with some of his departmental people and his Cabinet colleagues in order to see whether we cannot get more charter flights to service these large electorates.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill asks the airline industry to collect the departure tax. This is another trend in government. It is just like the excise tax that farmers are now being asked to collect. I pointed this out to the House last week. Only half the farmers are receiving the excise rebate because the rest probably do not have the time to do all the paper work. Because the airline industry is collecting the tax it will cost the Government only $1.5m to collect $50m in a year. That is not bad business. The great trend in government today is that it is moving all its tax collecting responsibilities and costs across to private industry. That is a great cost to private industry and just another added burden. Not only does industry have to collect the tax, but it is also paying more tax to this Government in all sorts of areas.

I wish to emphasise that it is important that we should continue to service inland Australia. There has been a contraction of services. I also wish to mention the fact that apparently international airlines can carry passengers within Australia. To start with, there are too many international airports. The Chairman of Qantas Airways Ltd was in Parliament House talking to us the other day and he made a valid point. For example, Port Hedland is an international airport. When one sets up an international airport one must supply all the personnel involved in quarantine and passport control. Quite a staff is involved. That area should be looked at because I am sure these large numbers of staff could be cut down. As I was saying, international carriers can carry passengers from Cairns to Brisbane, for instance, but the domestic carriers cannot. Therefore, we are losing a lot of revenue. Australia is losing a lot of overseas income and the domestic carriers are losing revenue. If Singapore Airlines, or any other airline that flies into Cairns, is then allowed to carry passengers to Brisbane or Sydney, revenue is going back to Singapore or whichever country owns the airline. This practice was pointed out to me the other day and until then I did not know it was happening. I believe that the Minister should be looking at this matter. I give my very limited support to the Bill. I think it is a great pity that the Government cannot totally withdraw this tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that I am going to upset my colleague the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) when I say that in October of 1978 the House of Representatives Select Committee on Tourism, of which I was the Chairman, recommended the introduction of a departure tax on people leaving Australia. It is interesting to look at that recommendation some eight years down the track. We recommended the introduction of a $10 departure tax. We also recommended that that tax should be used to promote international tourism to Australia. I wonder how far really we have come in the last eight years? I must say to the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris), who is at the table, that at least some of this money is now going back into airport cost recovery programs; and, in that respect, I suppose we ought to be grateful.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the very real difficulties I had with the establishment of the departure tax was the setting up at airports around Australia of little cages containing bureaucrats who took $10 off people as they left Australia. If one looks at that initial recommendation of the Select Committee one finds that we also said that the responsibility for the collection of the departure tax should rest with the airlines. I wonder today just why we are going through some of the drama that is contained in the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill 1986 when it would seem to me to be an entirely simple procedure to have the departure tax written into the cost of the fare, as it is in most countries. In fact, something like 111 nations impose some sort of tax on departing passengers. It does not really matter whether it is called a departure tax, a sales tax on a ticket or an airport users tax.

According to my latest research, 29 countries impose a departure tax along the lines adopted by Australia inasmuch as a bureaucrat puts a little ticket on the front of departing passengers' tickets and another little bureaucrat stamps the tickets to confirm that the departure tax has been paid. This seems to me to be absolutely crazy. People may say: `Well, it is going to be very hard to introduce a different system in Australia'. I also remind honourable members and the Minister at the table that a departure tax of sorts is already levied at one of our airports. That tax happens to be included in the price of the ticket and appears in a separate box on the ticket. I refer to the procedure adopted at Cairns Airport where in fact a passenger charge is levied on everybody who uses that airport. If one happens to be going through Cairns one will see provision for an additional cost of $2 in the bottom corner of one's ticket. If we are to continue to levy a departure tax it would seem to me eminently sensible that this is the way we should do it. We should do what something like 81 other countries around the world do-make sure that the cost of the departure tax is included in the fare. It would then be a relatively easy process to have that amount of money settled with the Government.

We have heard all sorts of dramas in this debate about the very real problems that the airlines themselves are facing in collecting this tax. I suppose that when we speak about departure tax we are speaking primarily about international air travellers. I acknowledge that some additional facilities are available for collecting departure tax from people using ships and other means of transport. However, most of the ticket collection that is done in Australia is in fact done by our own national airline, Qantas Airways Ltd. The staff of Qantas pull the tickets for most of the 20 international airlines which are operating in Australia. While it may be an imposition on Qantas to come around to this particular means of accounting, it would seem to me that to do it that way would be a much cleaner operation. If Qantas collected virtually all those ticket butts, it would then be relatively easy to calculate what would be required to settle government charges.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the tickets which are sold overseas?

—That is a relatively simple situation too; it could be handled quite easily. If we really wanted to we probably could take this whole operation out of the hands of the airlines and arrange for one of the international settling bodies, which distribute the amount of money that is owed to various airlines on multistage tickets, to collect that tax for us. It would seem to be much more sensible to go down that path and have a very clean operation. We would be able to do away with the extra staff required; we would do away with the security problems; and, most importantly, we would do away with that bad bit of public relations at airports that arises when people who have had a good time in Australia find all of a sudden that they have to come up with another $20 before they can leave the country.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite interesting to look back over some of the evidence that the Select Committee on Tourism took in regard to the whole area of departure tax. The duty free shop operations are one of the organisations that in fact lose money because of the imposition of a departure tax. Two things happen: Either people have to pay their last $20 rather than spend it at a duty free shop or they get such a bad taste in their mouth that they say: `Well, we will wait till the next stop and buy a bottle of whisky in Singapore or elsewhere'. That very real problem was raised.

The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) mentioned in his very excellent contribution today that perhaps we should be looking at spending more money overseas on international promotions for tourism. This would be particularly advisable at the moment when we consider exactly what is happening in terms of overseas tourism. I saw some figures just this morning to the effect that the American travel operators have reported a 75 per cent cancellation rate for Americans taking holidays to Europe this summer. They are looking for somewhere else to go. There has also been a dramatic drop off in the number of people from the northern areas of Europe, such as the Scandinavian countries, and the Federal Republic of Germany who have traditionally spent their summer holidays in the Greek Islands, Italy, the south of France, Spain and Portugal. Hundreds of thousands of these people will not be taking their holidays in those areas. Also, even tourists who go through to places like the Maldives and Sri Lanka, which is fairly current in today's climate, and indeed to East Africa, are starting to cancel their trips because they usually have to go through either a Middle Eastern port or Athens Airport to get there.

Never before in our history has Australia had such an ideal opportunity to promote the concept of inbound tourism. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) keeps telling us that we do not have the infrastructure to handle such an increase in tourism. We have plenty of infrastructure. I appeal to the Government to do the quickest job we can to get out and start doing some more promotion in the North American market. There is no doubt that the promotion that has been undertaken so far has worked very well. The increase of 80 per cent in the number of visas issued to Americans to come to Australia is to be applauded. There is no reason why that 80 per cent cannot be tripled if we can convince some of the Americans who traditionally have gone to Europe that Australia is a good and safe place to visit and that they will get excellent value for money because of the devaluation of our dollar. If that is not possible, if the Government cannot see its way clear to divert some of these considerable funds, which amount to $48m to $50m this year, into some instant promotion in North America, Northern Europe and Japan in an effort to increase the tourism numbers from those countries, perhaps we should look at the proposition that the Minister has given in the Bill now before us and make sure that some of the funds go back into the airport cost recovery program.

On that point I would like to take issue with the Minister in regard to a statement he made in the last week or so when he visited the new development of the Brisbane International Airport. There is no doubt, as the Minister rightly said, that it is going to be the most magnificent airport in Australia. I am sure that we will soon see Brisbane become the No. 2 airport behind Sydney in terms of international traffic using the facility. One thing that worries me is the statement by the Minister about the Brisbane international air terminal. Honourable members of this House would know that, although we have this magnificent development at Brisbane Airport, we are in fact keeping the old airport terminal which was designed as a storage shed during the time Mr Charles Jones was Minister for Transport, as part of the new international airport program. This storage shed has been converted to handle international traffic. The visit by the Minister on a Wednesday afternoon was probably not terribly well timed because, quite frankly, at that time one could probably fire a cannon down the international airport and not hit anyone.

May I suggest that at some time in the near future the Minister go to the Brisbane International Airport terminal on a Saturday morning, when something like 12 to 14 international flights are handled, or on a Friday afternoon when there are 9 or 10 international flights being handled and the place is in absolute chaos. I know that the Minister can argue that the Public Works Committee recommended to this place some years ago that the new international airport terminal not go ahead at that particular time. However, that decision was made prior to Brisbane being granted the Commonwealth Games and Expo 88. We all know that Brisbane has an excellent chance of being the host city for the 1992 Olympics. All those things indicate to me that we will have absolute chaos in that terminal if we do not get our new facility up and running.

I make a special appeal to the Minister that he look at every possibility of proceeding as soon as possible with that new Brisbane International Airport complex. The situation is that we expect something like 700,000 international visitors to Queensland for Expo 88. Admittedly, not all of those people will come through Brisbane International Airport but a great proportion of them will fly into Brisbane for Expo 88. The use of that terminal by an additional 700,000 passengers will cause some real problems. I sincerely hope that the Minister will look at the proposition of upgrading that airport facility as soon as possible by way of the introduction of a new terminal.

I sincerely hope too that at some time in the not too distant future we will see some rationality in the whole area of the collection of a departure tax. The Opposition is not opposed to the departure tax. We can see the necessity for it and we can see the value of it, whether it be poured into the international tourism or airport cost recovery program. However, we think it is really quite crazy to go through the drama which we are going through at the moment in terms of the collection of the tax when it is a relatively simple operation to have the cost of the departure tax included in the ticket. We could have the cost of the departure tax written into that ticket and the ticket cleared, ensuring the security for the Government of the total amount going back into its coffers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support the call that has been made by honourable members on this side of the House for the Government to make every endeavour to streamline the way in which the departure tax is collected. There is no doubt that currently it is making a contribution to the problem of congestion at our major airports. Along with that, it is causing a great deal of unfortunate reaction from those travellers whom we want to arrive in and depart from this country with a minimum of fuss. I think that `a minimum of fuss' was one of the sales promotions of British Airways at one stage. Perhaps we can learn from some of our overseas visitors and those countries that operate into and out of this country about ways and means of discerning the prospects of achieving that.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that there are points of entry and departure around the world where there is a more expeditious processing of a departure tax. My colleagues on this side of the House have referred to what is occurring in some locations. I remind the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) that many of the airports which are under local ownership in Australia impose a departure charge, a levy, and that is not seen by the travelling public at all. That cost is contained within the ticket sold by an airline and it has the responsibility to ensure that it returns to the authority involved the amount that is required to be collected. Surely that is an example of a minimum of fuss. I know that because we are dealing with overseas sales of tickets there may be some more difficult factors arising, but the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) has touched on that in an effective way.

I know that the Minister would be the first to want to see something practical done in this matter. However, I urge him to look a little beyond what is being put to him by his officials on this score: Perhaps the regulations as they are drawn are too stringent and perhaps it is a matter of producing a more practical approach to avoid the difficulties that apparently the airlines have expressed in relation to this matter. If they are reluctant, that is unfortunate. If the process of collection is a simple one, the airlines ought to be given a pretty clear message that they had better not be reluctant from here on because we have too much bureaucracy involved in the handling of passenger departures from most of our major airports. In fact, I suppose it is fair to say that that is so currently for all of them.

I find that that is so every time I go near either the international airport in Sydney or the international airport in Brisbane. That is so likewise for a lot of my constituents who travel through both airports. I hear horrendous accounts of the difficulties they encounter. The collection of the departure tax is part of the problem that contributes to the difficulty of movement, the difficulty of processing and the difficulty of being able to cope with what is required of people from the moment they step on to the kerb in front of the terminal building to the time they end up in the departure lounge and are able to board the aircraft. If we cannot do a little to simplify that, it is a reflection on the contribution that we have made to world aviation over so many years. We have been the first in many fields. Let us be the first to simplify the process of departure tax collection while still getting the result that is essential from the point of view of collecting the tax. I suppose that the word `tax' suggests that there is something punitive about it, but there need not be.

I want to say a quick word on another aspect. Now that part of this revenue is being used for cost recovery, I hope that the Minister will review some of the immediate problems confronting travellers who want to reach the international airport to start with. I refer to the moves currently under way. Let me instance Brisbane. I came through Brisbane this afternoon. I flew from my home city of Grafton to Brisbane on an East-West Airlines Ltd flight to join a Trans-Australia Airlines flight to Canberra this afternoon. The turnaround time at Brisbane Airport was 30 minutes. As from next week East-West will be obliged to use another point of arrival at the Brisbane Airport. It is a kilometre away from the other domestic terminals. That means that people travelling from my constituency who want to get an international flight in Sydney and whose time scales are such that they would like to use the East-West scheduled movement could find once East-West is obliged to be a kilometre away from the other domestic terminals that there is no way that they could make a connection.

Why is it that there cannot be an adequate arrangement for airlines to use the facilities provided at the airports? I know that there are leases and I know that there are contractual arrangements. Surely within the framework of those contractual arrangements, if we are to have an effective system of internal services to link with our international services, there must be at least the scope for adequate provision for the travelling public-not a circumstance which seems to be arising now of a war between all the domestic airlines, with the travelling public being the losers. To my mind that is something that the Government should address, and address fairly firmly.

The report issued today by the committee reviewing air services in New South Wales suggests further competition between the airlines. Does that spell out to us a further circumstance in which the competition will result in such a fierce attitude between the domestic airlines that they will not let people walk through their terminal buildings to catch other services? If that is what we are coming to in this country, we had better learn fast that we will not be able to do anything to impress, to attract or to handle international tourists. What is the use of having international tourist traffic coming into this country if it is not then able to use our domestic services in an easy, comfortable and effective way.

In conclusion, I appeal to the Minister to look very closely at this very great challenge that is confronting us at the moment. It is one that very soon will overtake all of the interests in aviation, to the detriment of the travelling public, unless a firm line is taken, unless a firm stand is taken, by the Government in respect of the use of our airports. I refer to domestic, international and locally owned airports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank those honourable members who have participated in the debate-from the Opposition, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) and the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson), and the Government members, the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) and the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth). It has been a wide-ranging discussion, with most of it being outside the confines of the legislation. But I think it has been of interest and much of it has been constructive and put forward in a positive manner. One sour note came from the honourable member for McPherson. I will come back to that.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Murray referred to congestion at check-in desks. We do have under way arrangements and moves to improve the allocation of check-in desks in the international terminal of the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport to overcome that problem. It is a long-standing problem which should not have been allowed to carry on for year after year. Currently, about 65 per cent of outgoing passengers are required to move through about 32 per cent of the desks that are available. That is not satisfactory and it will not be allowed to continue. But it takes a little time to make the arrangements to change the situation.

The honourable member wanted departure tax expenses incurred by airlines to be attributable for cost recovery purposes. Indirectly, that will happen because any reduced expense in the collection of the tax-in the way the cost recovery system and the attribution of the departure tax are treated-will mean that there will be a net improvement in cost recovery arising from that change. The honourable member suggested that stamps be provided to airlines on a 60-day basis. The actual credit period is a matter that is under discussion. There are other higher departure taxes in the world. The tax in New Zealand, for instance, is $A31.50, compared with the $20 tax in Australia. In the case of Hong Kong it is $A21.24. I will not go into detail on this point because it has been covered in other speeches that have been made.

The honourable member says that there should be more co-operation. Certainly there has been the utmost co-operation from me and I think that has been recognised, particularly by Opposition speakers. The honourable member for Fadden made that point very clearly. But, as the honourable member for Page rightly referred to, there comes a point when co-operation on the part of the other party becomes reluctance. How far does one go when there is reluctance? There comes a point at which the change must be made and one must be a little firmer. I thank the honourable member for Page for his encouragement in that regard. In regard to the encouragement he gave to international airlines, and the guarantee of co-operation, I can understand that point. They have co-operation. But, as I said, there comes a point when there must be some balance and reality about what we can do.

The simple fact is that international airlines-both those that are not based in this country and our own-are major transport businesses. They are not here because they like us or because they love to fly to the south of the globe; they are here to make money. We expect them, like any other business, to operate in a way that respects conditions in this country. They must make their fair and reasonable contribution to the costs incurred in providing the services, and do that as efficiently as possible. We have tried to treat everybody on a similar basis. But let us not think for a moment that they are here to provide some sort of special benefit to Australia. They are here-and many more are banging on the door, wanting to get in-because they want to grab some of the Australian market.

The honourable member for Canning, in his thoughtful and constructive way, expressed a number of views on the changes being made. I am grateful for that. Similarly, I am grateful to the honourable member for Perth. The only sour note in the debate was the attitude of the honourable member for McPherson. I think it is regrettable that, during what has otherwise been a very positive and constructive debate, he chose to indulge in a personal attack on a Minister. The Standing Orders provide ways and means, if he wants to pursue that course, for him to move a substantive motion and go down that track. I think it was unfortunate, and I say no more about it.

Let me say that some of the problems he mentioned about airports are not of our creation; they are a legacy, as was rightly referred to by the honourable member for Maranoa. This is one of a number of things we are finding the Fraser Government did that we do not think are right today. The honourable member said it all for me, and that summarises it. I suggest that the honourable member for McPherson should talk more with the honourable member for Maranoa. Their electorates are almost next door to one another; I think the electorate of the honourable member for Fadden is one that separates them. As I recall, the Liberal-National Party members of the Public Works Committee in 1979 recommended that the Brisbane Airport development should not go ahead and that the air strip site should not be changed. It is no good coming to me seven years later and saying: `Why haven't you done this or that?' Opposition members' predecessors-some of them are still here-did not want that done.

Reference was made by the honourable member for Murray to sales of departure tax stamps at post offices and exemptions. That is a matter that can be discussed by the airlines. What I have said to the airlines is in line with the comments made by the honourable member for Fadden. The present arrangements represent an impediment to the handling of people through international airports. As he correctly says, they leave a sour taste in the mouths of those who are confronted at the last moment by these arrangements. Many times there is a degree of embarrassment because people have exhausted all of their Australian currency. Australians leaving to go abroad find at the very last moment that they are called upon to produce Australian currency. It is not so much a money problem because the $20 represents a very small percentage of the cost of the journey. It is more the embarrassment, I believe, that causes the offence. We would like to see as many of those tax stamps as possible sold off-airport.

During discussions the airlines ultimately said that the stamps could not be incorporated in the actual ticket, as the honourable member for Fadden suggested. They could not do that for one reason or another. So we came to this arrangement: `All you have to do is to make sure that each outgoing passenger has a departure tax stamp affixed to the ticket. I am not very much concerned about how it gets there, so long as we collect the revenue for it and you ensure that each of your passengers has one of those stamps affixed to his or her ticket'.

The sensible and logical thing to do would be to encourage as much as possible the sale of those stamps off-airport, whether it be through travel agents, the airline offices or, at the point of last resort, on-airport. That would certainly streamline the facilities. The problem is that the airport terminals that we have were not built to handle the numbers that they are required to handle today and they cannot be quickly expanded to take increased numbers. So we must make the best possible use we can of the space we have and the facilities we have. We can certainly, in my view, make better use of the facilities than has been the case. We should remove this impediment of having to line up in yet one more queueing operation in the airport to collect departure tax stamps. I am confident, having come to this current arrangement with the airlines, that they will be able to find a better way than applies under the existing system.

I will very quickly mention the other matters that have been raised by honourable members. The honourable member for McPherson commented about the strike at the departure tax booths in Sydney a few weeks ago. No one could disagree that that caused this country lamentable embarrassment; but I do not think there is any point in constantly reminding everybody, in case they had forgotten, that it happened. The more important thing is to get on with finding a positive answer and getting over to the new arrangements as quickly as possible. That matter was not my responsibility; but it was dealt with as quickly as possible, given the circumstances at the time.

The suggestions regarding the use of the proceeds of the tax from the airlines and the sale of the stamps are various options that can be looked at. The airlines have suggested to me that the stamps could be sold in post offices. I am prepared to discuss that and to listen to them in a reasonable way as we go along. The honourable member for Bass said that more money should be spent on tourism and that labour costs at hotels were too high. The first point was made by a number of speakers, but it does not have anything to do with this debate. We are spending a record amount on tourism. We are getting record results. If we look at the figures, we see that there has been an increase of about 520,000 in the number of persons going out through international airports. The projected figure for 1985-86 is 2.595 million, compared with 2.075 million in 1982-83-a massive increase. That is producing results.

I say simply, on a political point, that that was not the view taken by the Fraser Government. As the honourable member for Fadden rightly pointed out, he recommended, as Chairman of the House of Representatives Select Committee on Tourism at the time, that the money should go to tourism. But the then Government said: `Thanks for the money. We will use it for something else'. Because it is now cost-attributable-a decision of this Government-an amount of it is being spent indirectly on the improvement of airports and airport facilities.

As to Darwin Airport wanting a decision, I made it clear the other day that we will not be in a position at the end of this week to make an announcement on that. Due to a number of factors, it may be the best part of two months. The problem there is that, again, we were talking about a very large amount of money-$100m to $108m worth of expenditure-which cannot possibly be borne by the number of people going through that airport. The fact remains that the problem at Darwin, putting aside the equality of facilities-nobody disputes their inadequacy, we are very much aware of that, and let us not have any discussion or difference about that-in management terms is that 64 per cent of Darwin airport movements are within about two hours. For the other 22 hours not much is happening and the other 36 per cent is spread over 22 hours with two thirds of the activities being crammed into two hours.

One could ask whether scheduling could not be changed. It comes back to making the best and proper use of public money and investment and ultimately it comes back to management, which is one of the problems that must be looked at. Certainly the airlines themselves could take a stronger look at how they are scheduling. We understand that it is the end of the line for them, but there is always a better way if it is looked at hard enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —Curfews.

—The honourable member for Wide Bay mentions curfews. I do not know whether he means Darwin or elsewhere such as the ports of origin or intermediate points. However, the point is that when two-thirds of the movement are within two hours out of 24, one has to look very hard at how much money can be spent. Whatever money is spent has to be spent on the basis that the industry itself has to pick it up later. Any over investment in airports pushes up the levels of air fares and we are looking at that relationship.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Maranoa mentioned that one of the many things that the Fraser Government did was to bring in the departure tax. It is one of the things, like others, with which we do not agree these days, he said: I will not mention his comment about the Department of Aviation. It was a silly comparison made on the number of Department of Aviation employees per general aviation aircraft registered. It ignores completely the fact that about 80 per cent of our nation is down in one corner and that we have to provide services right across Australia. I just make one point: It is no good people coming to me complaining about the cost of aviation service, which we are moving to reduce and whose efficiency we are improving when, at the same time, those movements to improve our efficiency are then combated or opposed by the very people who complain that it costs too much. They cannot have it both ways-they cannot complain that the cost is too great and that expenditure is too high and, when we move to reduce expenditure to improve efficiency, they then scream, `Heh, you can't take that away'. Again, it comes back to value for money for the taxpayer.

I have mentioned the points made by the honourable member for Fadden. There was a positive and constructive strain in what he was saying and certainly our thinking to an extent is going in a similar direction. It is a matter of getting the best possible service in those terminals. We have been looking very hard at that. What we are going to do in the Sydney international terminal, I am confident will streamline the handling of people. We can get people through that terminal much better than we are doing now, but honourable members must recognise that the other areas involved in processing are not under the Department of Aviation and are not part of this ministry. It is a matter of co-ordinating, looking at immigration and looking at Customs. We have set up a special task force in Sydney chaired by the Department of Aviation to bring together for the first time all those people involved to try to get better arrangements for the staffing of those booths and the handling of people concerned. We have one major problem, namely, that the luggage conveyor facilities at Sydney were built to handle groups of 150 to 180 people. The carousels simply cannot handle luggage in quantities for 400 people. That is a straight physical problem and they have to be replaced with conveyors. None of those task is easy, but the other aspect of people processing is a top priority and we will be moving to try to improve them as quickly as possible.

The comments made by the member for Page were similarly put in a positive and constructive way that we should try to be flexible and streamlined in the handling of people and their luggage through airports. Airports are people places. People going through airports generally, particularly international terminals, are under stress. They are arriving after a long journey to this country, they are tired, fatigued or stressed in having travelled or, alternatively, they are departing on a long journey and the same things apply. Through the Federal Airports Corporation we will give very great emphasis to passenger convenience and handling efficiency. Those things will be done and we are very much aware of them. I appreciate the remarks that have been put forward to simplify procedures and to help people as the honourable member for Page says, and to get them straight into the departure lounge. That is also a factor related to airport security. One of the great difficulties in airports abroad is not the departure lounges but rather the public areas. The point made by the honourable member for Page I accept in that spirit as it has some meaning.

In my last few words I thank the Opposition for its support and thank my colleagues on this side of the House for their contributions and support. The Government is making a priority of improving efficiency and convenience within the airports. The new arrangements for departure tax sales will assist that. We will overall, I believe, get a much better result for the taxpayer than with the existing arrangement. I commend the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
