DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILL:WHEAT MARKETING AMENDMENT BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 April, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have proposed a cognate debate for the two Bills as they make a number of parallel reforms to the administration of the wheat and meat marketing authorities. The Opposition supports these desirable changes to the operation of the Wheat Board and the Meat and Livestock Corporation. The changes reduce the day-to-day involvement of the Government in the operation of these two marketing authorities. These Bills are the first in a sequence of legislation which will implement reforms affecting the statutory marketing authorities of 10 farm industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The process for change was set in train during the term of the previous Government when actions were commenced to enable government business undertakings, especially transport business undertakings, to operate in a more commercial manner, but with proper accountability. A White Paper was produced in the late 1970s, but it was clear that statutory authorities in primary industry area warranted consideration separate to other types of authorities such as Trans Australia Airlines which did not serve a specific industry base. The four largest farm industries affected by these changes are wool, wheat, meat and dairying. I understand that the Dairy Corporation reforms will be introduced into the Parliament shortly.

I note with pleasure that the Australian Wool Corporation, which already enjoys some of the flexibilities introduced by these Bills, has achieved great prominence in the world market scene. The Wool Corporation is a shining example of what can be achieved by government marketing authorities for thousands of producers. Under the Chairmanship of Mr David Asimus, the Wool Corporation has brought the Australian wool industry into a position of leadership on the world export markets, despite the general downturn in farm commodity prices. The most important changes in these wheat and meat Bills relate to finance, staffing and the replacement of some day-to-day ministerial approval requirements with annual operational and longer-term corporate plans.

Quite clearly it is sensible and intelligent to provide that flexibility to these corporations and to these boards when particular effort is being made to attract people of high calibre with managerial experience, commercial experience and financial experience to operate these corporations on behalf of their industries. It is vital that our authorities have greater flexibility in their commercial transactions, for several reasons. There have been rapid developments in the world monetary system. With more than 70 per cent of Australian farm produce sold overseas, we simply cannot afford to lag behind these developments.

To its credit, the Hawke Government carried on the moves towards deregulation of the Australian financial system which were set in train by the Liberal-National Party Government and the establishment of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. Against this backdrop it would be illogical to maintain controls which slow down the financial decision-making process within our marketing authorities in a day and age where time means money and delays can be very costly. For example, the Australian Wheat Board will now be equipped to trade in a wider range of futures or currency contracts and in interest and currency swaps under clause 7 of the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill. The Board will also be able to take up an equity interest in subsidiary companies if this would improve its financial and administrative performance. Such equity interest actions will remain the subject of ministerial control and will need to be spelt out in the annual and corporate plans.

The Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation will no longer need ministerial approval for borrowings unless the amount totals $5m or more in one financial year. The Corporation will also enjoy more autonomy in the lending of its reserves. Accountability to the Minister for Primary Industry will be maintained through the annual plans and the three to five year corporate plans-and to the industry through the annual general meeting. On this point, I raise one concern: There is a case for a review of the procedure under which the Meat and Livestock Corporation and the associated Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation hold their annual meetings. Great play has been made by the Government on the annual meeting serving as the ultimate means of accountability to the industry. Yet I detect rather widespread concern over a motion to increase levies which was put to the last meeting. The increased charges per beast slaughtered were lumped into a motion covering both cattle and sheep when, in fact, the new fees should have been dealt with separately. Delegates did not have the option of splitting the motion for voting purposes and a vote of 75 per cent against the motion was required for it to be vetoed. It was not simply 75 per cent of those at the meeting, but rather 75 per cent of all registered producers and 75 per cent of all processors, simultaneously, at the meeting. Therefore, in practical terms, a veto was impossible. So I do think that some action needs to be taken to overcome that problem. I am not critical of the Minister in this respect because I think there are always a few growing pains. A few problems and anomalies occur in the early stages of a changed regime, but I understand that he has also had this matter brought to his attention. I hope some action is taken to overcome what is obviously rather a silly situation.

There is also growing concern amongst producers at the high costs of these annual meetings and the difficulty being experienced in organising the two meetings back to back to minimise expenses. These are matters to which the Minister must turn his attention. I would be grateful at the end of the debate if he would give some indication as to whether he has some plan in mind to overcome that problem. It is no good proclaiming the annual meetings as the ultimate in accountability to the industry if the delegates are hamstrung. However, the Opposition maintains its support in principle for accountability to the industry and to Parliament. We will continue to monitor the feedback from the producers and the industry for that matter to ensure the best interests of the producers are protected.

Another change to the commercial dealings of the statutory marketing authorities will be their ability to appoint outside auditors instead of the Auditor-General. We support the safeguards written into these Bills, which include the option for the Auditor-General to intervene if necessary, but at government expense. The Auditor-General will draw up a list of potential commercial auditors from which the authority will make its selection if its decides to make the switch. Appointment of staff will become a more direct responsibility of the authority with all bodies enjoying the powers now exercised by the Wool Corporation.

A range of less important changes are also introduced by these Bills. They have been studied by the Opposition and attract no criticism. Both the wheat and meat authorities will be subject to a reserve power of direction from the Minister. Given that the farm industries are characterised by the existence of many thousands of producers, it is imperative that the Federal Government maintain a reserve power of intervention where their corporate interest is at stake. In each case the exercise of that power will have to be notified to the Chief Executive and will need to be gazetted. These notifications will be laid before the Parliament for 15 days and will be subject to disallowance. Interestingly these requirements bear a close similarity to the rules which applied over the Minister's recent attempt to amend the export control orders following the Mudginberri dispute. I hope that he would not attempt to sneak through the Parliament any exercise of his reserve powers under the provisions of this legislation in the same manner as his attempt to obtain a cop-out clause should a Mudginberri-type situation recur.

The Parliament has disallowed those orders. Let us be clear about the parallel. The export orders were gazetted in late February and introduced quietly into the Parliament in March without a statement. The only public announcement was a Press release about six weeks before they were quietly slipped into the Parliament. I think there is something wrong with the Standing Orders when that sort of thing can be done. I think the Standing Orders should be changed somewhat.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want all the regulations laid on the table. You don't read the ones that are given to you.

—It is the way these orders are handed in. They are handed in to the Clerk of the House and then they do not appear again until we see a note of them in Hansard. In this case, had the Opposition and the meat industry not been vigilant, the 15 sitting days might well have expired before anyone recognised what had been done. There is an obligation on the Minister to clearly advise the industries and the public at large should the Government intend to exercise a general reserve power over a marketing authority. This is not an obligation written into these Bills, but it should be considered as a moral obligation.
—Hear, hear!

—I thank the honourable member. That support was necessary. These Bills are a move towards decentralisation of powers away from the Government. That is to be commended even if the powers relate only to some day to day commercial and administrative actions. It is too much to hope that the same zeal will be extended to the more critical economic policy areas such as wage fixation, health care, et cetera. It is my responsibility as the shadow spokesman, to place these Bills in their right perspective. Any change which gives the Meat and Live-stock Corporation and the Wheat Board greater flexibility on world markets deserves the support of members on both sides of the House, but the stark truth is that any savings to producers from these changes will be quite small, if any, when compared with the effects of other actions by the Government. This is not to say that greater flexibility and more commercial orientation will not benefit producers in the longer term because of the application of better market wisdom and better judgment in respect to actions that are taken and the administration of the activities of these authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at that against the background of some of the actions that the Government has taken which have belted primary producers over the last three years forestalling what should have been a total recovery from the devastating drought in 1983. I know marketing is very important, but what is most important to the producers generally is the bottom line at the end of the financial year where the farmers are able to make a profit. Two factors are involved in profit: There is the price for the product on the one hand-if it is wheat, the Wheat Board is the authority for selling that product-and on the other the costs of production that are incurred in that product. In more recent times the difficulty has been that, with high interests rates, high costs of delivery, high costs of transport, and high input costs, the margins have become smaller and smaller so that in this financial year we are going to see farmers receive the lowest returns in real terms since records have been kept. The only other time when they were low, of course, was right in the depths of the 1982-83 drought. The rural statement which the Minister for Primary Industry handed down a week or two ago hands back less than a quarter of the $442m.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Less than one-quarter of the $442m of resources that have been cut away from the Primary Industry Department in the various budgetary decisions taken and announced in this Parliament since 1983. Even the rural statement of a couple of weeks ago slipped in a few more nasties. We still do not know whether the farm loss quarantining measure has been reversed. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) stands by his claim that it has not been reversed; he claims that it has been modified. The Minister for Primary Industry says that it has been reversed. I do not suppose we will known until we see the colour of the legislation in this Parliament. As I said earlier, it is one thing to be freeing up markets and freeing up the operations of these boards or marketing operations and another thing not to take actions to take the load of costs off the farmers' backs at a time when world commodity prices are obviously in great difficulty.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will be interested to dig a little deeper so far as this quarantining issue is concerned, I am sure. There is no doubt that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) probably knows what he is on about, but he is not saying, and nor is the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). At page 59 of the booklet issued on 15 April in half a dozen very loose sentences we are told that breeders of stud livestock will face a new $10m tax slug. This is going to be particularly serious to the meat and livestock industries. That is what this legislation is all about. One of these Bills is about the meat and livestock industries and the selling of products from those animals. Of course, lying in the background are the studs which provide the genetic material necessary to ensure that we have a quality product. I do not think it is good enough that the details are extremely unclear.

What we can glean is that the natural increase in livestock will be subject to a percentage increase of thousands in tax valuation for the year of birth. The livestock declaration will have to include costs of progeny development, including stud servicing fees and costs associated with ovum fertilisation and implantation, gestation and birth. Accountants to whom I have spoken are quite unclear as to whether this measure introduces new costs into the tax bill, or whether it is bringing forward a liability which would have been payable further down the track. Either way, it will be a burden at a time when many farm producers are in big financial trouble. As I said earlier, whilst it is very important to make sure that these corporations are operating in a commercial sense and that the Minister and the Government are not meddling in the day to day operations of these organisations, it is still of vital importance to ensure that those who are having their products sold are not being hamstung by burdens that could well be relieved from the industry. What justification is there for taking a tax liability out of the year when a profit is realised forward to a time when the new asset is capable of nil profit? Further, the measures will add $10m to government revenue in 1988-89 but, we are told, negligible amounts in other years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there no end to it?

—I hope that there is an end to it and I hope that this Government realises that it has gone too far. The new tax rule will apply, we are told, from July this year. That in itself gives producers little or no time to plan ahead. Given a cattle gestation period of nine months, or five months for sheep, how does the Government calculate that the changes that I have been taking about will not take effect for two years? I call for a full and immediate explanation of these changes by way of ministerial statement to Parliament, either by the Treasurer or by the Minister responsible for this legislation. Clearly accountants and stud stock owners have a right to know and, as we are nearing the end of the financial year, need to know whether or not they will be up for more tax this year and, if so, to what extent.
—They are supposed to be helping farmers.

—That is exactly right. The odd piece of good news from the Government, such as these Bills, tends only to mask far more significant measures which are pulling down our rural trade performance and the living standards of people in the country towns and cities. Last week the Minister attempted twice in Parliament to defend his inaction on the positive and effective measures outlined in my 14-point plan tabled in this House in February.
—The best and fairest plan I have ever seen.

—That is so right, and I am very pleased that the honourable member is well aware of that plan. The Minister has done his best to make sure that everybody is aware of the plan, because he has discussed it in this Parliament. But the Minister tripped himself up badly because, in costing the plan, he suggested that Government revenue would be reduced by $2,766m but admitted that $2,487m, or 90 per cent of that cost, related to the savage fuel parity rip-offs. The Minister's own words-
—What has this to do with the Bill?

—It has a lot to do with the Bill because it has a lot to do with the product going on to the market through the Meat and Livestock Corporation and the Wheat Board. The honourable member knows that. There is nothing more important than fuel for the production of wheat. The Minister's own words are that to pass on the full benefit of lower world oil prices to the community-not just to farmers, but to motorists and fuel users generally-would cost the Government $2,300m. That is the first time that we have heard that figure, and that is the extent of the fuel rip-off. It is there for everyone to see. Add another $187m for the tricky six-monthly indexation of fuel excise and we see that the fuel rip-off is close to $2.5 billion per annum to pay for the long awaited tax cuts to satisfy the accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), who is sitting at the table, must be very disturbed because, on the one hand, he is trying to get the people tax cuts but, on the other hand, we have a Treasurer who is nullifying the benefit of the tax cuts by ripping-off the fuel system as the world market price has fallen. That is having a dreadful effect on those producing wheat and those producing beef. It really is quite an outrage that they are being hit in this particular way. To give honourable members an idea, the wheat industry is the biggest user of distillate in the farm industry. Off-road distillate rebates, which were restored after enormous efforts, cost the farmers $55m when this Government knocked them off, but we find that petrol used on farms now attracts an excise about three times the level it was when this Government took office and that the excise is costing farmers $164m per annum. The on-farm petrol excise bill has leapt $100m a year under this Government, yet those opposite steadfastly refuse to consider giving back to farmers some of their lost competitiveness by rebating that excise. The Wheat Board and the Meat and Livestock Corporation have a very important role to play in selling these products to overseas markets, but how on earth can one sell them profitably when this sort of input cost is being imposed on these industries at this time?

The other measures in the 14-point plan, as costed by the Minister, reveal another thing-that their costs would be minimal but their impact on farm industries and farm returns would be dramatic. Scrapping the capital gains tax would affect revenue by only $5m a year, but the tax has undermined the value of the land on which these animals are grazing and which farmers are farming. Export inspection charges, which are very important to the livestock industry, have leapt almost as quickly as the fuel excise. They have gone up 200 per cent, and they must be rebated in full.

I fail to see how the Government can claim any credit for its farm policies when it will not even give back the $442m it has taken from farmers in the three years it has been in office. I repeat my warning that the farm sector will not tolerate these attacks indefinitely. If any honourable member opposite thinks he can relax about the bush crisis, he ought to take a trip to the bush and find out for himself. I am sure honourable members would be shocked by the mood of frustration and anger. I do not like it, and I hate to see our farm industries torn about at a time of extremely difficult world markets. I hate to see the mood that is welling up in country Australia at present. Rural Australians are waiting for meaningful action from this Government, and their patience is all but spent.

Having said that, the Opposition does support this legislation. We wish it a speedy passage, but we also wish that the Government will pay proper regard in the discussions that will be going on between now and when the Budget is brought down to reviewing aspects of the farm package. Clearly, the farm package has not been good enough to meet the crisis that exists at present. Secondly, the Minister himself, three days after having announced his package to this Parliament, admitted that the United States Farm Bill will have a far more serious effect than he thought. He should go back to the drawing board because of the new-found concern about the effects of the United States Farm Act, as it is now, upon a number of very critical industries, such as the wheat industry, the cotton industry and certainly the rice industry. That legislation will have a critical effect. Of course, the dairy cow slaughter program in the United States of America will also have a critical effect because of the amount of manufacturing meat that will be thrown on to the market. I appeal to the Minister and to his colleagues to give further sympathetic consideration to those important points in that 14-point plan which, I can assure the Minister, I have advanced, in a constructive sense. It is no good criticising governments without putting forward constructive alternative propositions. These proposals were advanced for that purpose well before the Minister's statement was put together. I ask the Minister to go back to the drawing board and take on board most of those points that were outlined in February of this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) on the points that he made. I noticed that in the last part of his speech he at least spoke to the legislation. Having spent some years in opposition in the Queensland Parliament, I have always found it interesting how oppositions can talk about what should be done, but in this instance the honourable member had the opportunity over some eight years to do something for the rural sector and did nothing. It is quite surprising that he should talk about what should be done now because it is this Government that has done something about the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. It is this Government that has listened to the wishes of the grazing industry and the meat industry generally across this nation and decided to act.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill 1986 is to amend sections of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977 to give effect to Government policy on the reform of the Commonwealth primary industry statutory marketing authorities, the SMAs. I suggest that this is something that the grazing industry has wanted for a long time, but it has been the Hawke Government that has decided to act. To learn the background to this legislation one has to look back to November 1985 when Cabinet agreed to a range of reforms to primary industry SMAs and the AMLC, in particular to reform the requirement of ministerial approval over many aspects of the day to day operations of the Corporation. That is something that has been warranted, required and asked for for a long time, but nothing was done by the previous Government.

The proposals and reforms covered by this Bill are designed to increase the flexibility of the AMLC's appointment of auditors and its financial management. Again, this has been warranted and required previously. The legislation is also designed to provide the Minister for Primary Industry with a general reserve power of direction over the Corporation. The Bill provides that ministerial approval will no longer be required for a number aspects. Firstly, it will not be required for the purchase of property over $100,000 or for the purchase and sale for export of meat and livestock. It will no longer be required for the terms and conditions of employment of consultants. The AMLC will not have to come back to the Minister to seek approval for these measures. No longer will ministerial approval be required for the terms and conditions of employment of staff. So the list of areas in which we are giving more power to the AMLC goes on. I believe that the Parliament should welcome these changes and I am pleased that the Opposition is supporting the measures contained in this legislation.

I take the opportunity to raise a couple of matters and to reiterate some of the points that I raised in a previous debate when I spoke on the proposed consortium for Queensland and northern New South Wales. I appeal to the AMLC to look very carefully at the consortium or merger that will take place. It was admitted by Geoff Tancred in a recent publication of Australian Business and by Bruce Campbell in a report in the Northern Bulletin in Queensland and other Queensland papers that Tancred Brothers, Metro Meat, Walkers and Smorgons will come together to form a consortium which I believe will have a monopolistic effect on the beef industry in Queensland, New South Wales and, for that matter, Australia generally. I am told that that group intends to take over Borthwicks and that, in fact, that takeover is under way. We will see the removal or demise of some five major meat companies in this country. We will see instead the development of a monopoly that will have enormous control-control over some 40 to 50 per cent of the beef killed in this country; control over some 400,000 tonnes of beef in Queensland; control over a beef industry worth $1 billion. Total beef exports were worth $1.5 billion in the year 1984-85, and my figures show that these four companies, tying up Borthwicks as well, will control two-thirds of that.

The effect on the meat worker, as I have stated in this House previously, will be the loss of some 2,000 jobs. It surely must be an issue that concerns the AMLC. It must also concern the Corporation's member organisations, the Cattlemen's Union of Australia and the United Graziers Association, for I believe that it will mean a control over the price that will be meted out to the grazier and will thus affect 6,000 to 7,000 graziers in Queensland and Australia generally. It will mean the closure of the Merinda meatworks at Bowen, of the Queerah meatworks near Cairns and the Pentland meatworks near Charters Towers, and it will mean that the Bremer River meatworks near Ipswich shall never open.

It is no wonder that Bob Katter Jr, the Queensland Minister for Northern Development and Community Services, has spoken out against this legislation. It is no wonder that Vince Lester, the National Party Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations in Queensland, has called for an inquiry. I believe that these two Ministers understand the effect of this consortium. I point out that I understand and appreciate the need for rationalising the meat industry in Queensland. I understand, too, that when we have some 31 licensed meatworks in a State, 28 of which are export meatworks, working at a capacity of between 33 and 58 per cent, quite obviously efficiency is not there and the investment is not giving the return that it ought. But I come back to the point-I appeal to the AMLC to consider this matter-that this is not the way to rationalise the industry. SPEECH.PARA: I understand that there is a need to rationalise the meat industry in Queensland. We have seen the demise of many of the meatworks in New South Wales. I just want to make one further comment on this issue, because I have canvassed it on a prior occasion. I refer to the attitude of the graziers to contracts. It seems strange that, on the one hand, the graziers do not want contract price arrangements where they go to a sale yard and only one price is offered and they do not want to contact the meatworks and find that only one price is offered-some sort of one-contract price. On the other hand they are saying that whilst they want a competitive market, they want to lock the meat workers into a one-price, one-contract labour situation. I do not believe that will work. If the graziers want the co-operation of the meat unions they ought to rethink that proposition. I only hope that the Mudginberri mentality does not prevail and that the companies will rethink the consequences that they shall cause to come on hundreds upon hundreds of families in north Queensland, on others throughout the rest of Queensland and, eventually, on consumers generally.

In the few remaining minutes, I want to comment on the need for the AMLC to upgrade its consumer marketing. I am well aware of what it is doing. It is deeply involved in its short cut campaign, and that is to be commended. At the same time, I see room to manoeuvre further, particularly in the consumer area. I advocate that the AMLC ought to meet with the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations to rethink the whole concept of marketing of meat. I suppose there is no need to start some sort of conflict or competition between the white meats and the red meats, but the facts are that the red meat industry is getting done. In recent time, there has been a fall in the consumption of red meats. On a per capita basis per year it has dropped from 40.8 kilograms per person per year to 40.6 kilograms. While the total consumption has increased, this has occurred only because of the increase in population. There is a need for the AMLC to set in place a rule of consistency and certainty for the consumer. The 43 consumer movements that exist throughout this nation would certainly come to the aid of the AMLC, given that it followed such a policy. It is a policy that ought to prevail not only on the domestic market but also on the international market.

Earlier this year I had the privilege of going to South East Asia. While I was there, I was staying at the Sari Pacific. Amazingly, as I found in other parts of South East Asia, the New Zealanders were at it again. They had a meat display at the hotel where I was staying. They also had a tourist display. They were encouraging the Indonesians to try New Zealand beef. It brought home to me the message that I got in Kuala Lumpur and also in Singapore when talking to people in the Australian Trade Commission, to expatriates and to other Australians who were involved in industry in those two major cities of Kuala Lumpur and Singapore. I talked to them about buying Australian beef. They told me point blank that, whilst it was probably half the price of American beef, they could not depend on its quality. They were prepared to pay double the price for something that had been brought three times the distance because it had certainty and consistency.

There is a need for an aggressive approach in marketing and for the AMLC to rethink its policy, to get to the retailers and the processors and to come down with a firm policy of consistency and certainty. I suggest also that it have another hard look not just at the housewife and the domestic market in terms of the kitchen but also at the fast food industry, because it is being beaten in that industry. One should look at the developments with regard to white meat, and also, I suppose, at the fish industry, particularly with the types of fast seafood outlets that are being opened in the supermarkets. The sale of chicken meats and pork meats seems to be outstripping that of the red meats.

It is time we started looking at promoting red meats. I am parochial about it, I realise that. The grazing industry is vitally important in my area. We export 80 per cent of Australia's beef. We have a very important industry in central Queensland, and it is also vital to Queensland. So it is important to me that the AMLC continue its plan and its practice of trying to upgrade and improve domestic consumption. It can do this only be getting out in the market-place. There is a need to start selling steak fingers and not so much the shish kebab but kebabs. The Corporation must get down to dealing with those people who are now caught up in the fast food area. We tend nowadays to consume so much fast food, and I believe that the red meat industry could do much in this field.

I think that the reputation of Australia is very much in question when it comes to its meat. That is something that surprised me when I was overseas. I sometimes think that the reputation of Australian meat is in question even in the domestic market. Talking to restaurateurs they will tell one that people do not want to ask for a meat meal. They are not prepared to do that because they are not sure about it. This would surely have to be the message to the beef industry: It is not what it should be in terms of certainty; it is not what it should be in terms of consistency. People expect that. They are paying top dollars and they expect decent meals when they purchase them. The housewife expects decent meat when she purchases it. The person buying fast food expects the same thing.

There is a need for the AMLC to continue its practice and its policy and also to undertake a campaign which would involve the consumer movement. It is not the responsibility of the grazier. The grazier takes a farm-gate mentality. As soon as the cattle have left his property, that is the end of it. He is not involved, and one does not blame him for not being involved. So it comes back to the AMLC. I congratulate it for what it has done in the last three years under the policies of this Government. It has certainly adopted a new marketing approach. It has taken a new attitude which I think is commendable, but it needs to address this problem in the market-place and ensure that the consumption of red meat increases in 1985-86, 1986-87 and in many years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In com- mencing my speech tonight on the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill and the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill, I wish to reply to a couple of points made earlier by the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), when he was answering an interjection from one of my colleagues. He posed this question: What did the former Government do for primary industry and for farmers? I think I will give him a very good, quick answer. I say basically that what the former Government did was to restore the incentives to agriculture that were taken away by the Whitlam Government. In particular, it brought in the investment allowance, accelerated depreciation; it restored the superphosphate bounty, which the Whitlam Government so foolishly took away; it restored fuel freight equalisation; it introduced the income equalisation deposits scheme and improved the averaging provisions; and probably, most importantly of all, it abolished estate duties. I could go on, because there were many other things. I suggest that the honourable member check his facts before he makes such a silly statement.
—He made a fool of himself.

—That is right. In speaking to the Bills before the House, I wish to comment firstly on details of the Bills, particularly the parts that are common to both Bills. I shall then refer to some of their wider implications and to the challenges facing the meat and wheat industries and how those challenges related to the role of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and the Australian Wheat Board. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has made much of his Government's statement on the reform of Commonwealth primary industry's statutory marketing authorities. Both of these Bills are framed in accordance with that policy. Both, in some ways, reduce the direct involvement of the Minister in the operations of the respective boards and move towards the boards providing the Minister with a five-year corporate plan and an annual operation plan. Both these plans maintain the respective boards' accountability to Parliament. However, as I have said in this place before, we should be mindful that forcing statutory marketing boards to have their annual operating plans approved by the Minister may lead to undue interference by governments. I place on notice that we will watch the Minister closely to see how he uses this power in practice.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter that is cause for concern is the proposal in both Bills to allow the Minister to give general directions to the Corporation or the Board. The question arises as to how the Minister proposes to use this power of general direction. It would appear that the Minister has already used this power. I understand that he wrote to the heads of several statutory marketing boards directing them not to support the National Farmers Federation national agricultural promotion program entitled `You can't take the country out of our country'. Despite a clear undertaking by the NFF that this program would be absolutely non-political, the Minister not only refused to endorse the program, but also went further and apparently directed agricultural statutory marketing bodies, such as the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and the Australian Wheat Board, not to provide any funding for this program. Why did the Minister give such direction? Why, when such a program is likely to improve the understanding of agriculture in the cities, has the Minister refused to allow support for the NFF promotion program from bodies such as the Australian Wheat Board and the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation? These bodies could demonstrably benefit from their involvement in such a program, which would also assist a better understanding of their role in the community at large. The Minister should table the letter he sent to the boards of these authorities; otherwise doubts will remain as to how he really proposes to use the power of general direction as outlined in these Bills.

There is another matter I wish to raise with the Minister in relation to the operations of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation which has already been mentioned by the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Hunt). In my speech on the second reading of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Bill two years ago I mentioned a potential problem with the annual general meeting of the Corporation. In order to carry a motion not to increase levies, a motion of no confidence in the Chairman or a motion relating to the responsibilities of the Corporation a 75 per cent vote of livestock producers and 75 per cent support of processors is needed. As I said then, this will be almost unworkable in practice. I stand by that statement and again call on the Minister to re-examine this weakness relating to the annual general meetings of the Corporation. If the Government wants livestock producers and processors to be involved in the annual general meeting and take an interest in the Meat and Livestock Corporation, he had better look closely at this point.

Both the wheat and the meat industries are facing very challenging times. The problems facing agriculture in general, and these industries in particular, are well known and have been highlighted in this place on many occasions recently. It is worth reminding honourable members that we are talking about two of Australia's major export industries-wheat exports in the current financial year will total nearly $3 billion and meat and livestock exports will be worth $1.7 billion. When one considers the adverse balance of trade figures that this nation is experiencing right now-our exports are more than $1 billion behind our imports every month- one realises that the importance of these industries cannot be overstated. Wheat exports alone account for nearly 10 per cent of all exports from Australia, thus it can be seen that these are very important to the well being of our economic health. That is why many honourable members had hoped that the recent overseas mission of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) would lead to some success and that is why so many of us were so bitterly disappointed to find that the Prime Minister had headed off to the United States, supposedly to safeguard some of our export markets for wheat, only to find that even before he got to Washington the Americans were negotiating to take part of our market in North Yemen, a market that had until now been exclusively Australian. Then we found that the Americans had moved into Jordan, another market of ours and that they were planning to move into the Egyptian market, again one in which Australia has always traditionally been dominant. As I said in the House last week, it is results that count and the results that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) have achieved in protecting our export markets seem to be very few.

It is worth looking at our meat exports in some detail. In the past month we have seen a dramatic drop in the price of cows. In fact, in one week in some centres cow prices dropped by $100 a head-something almost unheard of. The reasons for this price drop are threefold: First, there are growing fears of drought in many parts of Australia; secondly, the United States market is being depressed by the decision of the United States Government to have a wholesale buyout of the American dairy herd; and thirdly, the value of the Australian dollar seems to defy gravity by rising against the American dollar. I say `defies gravity' because, considering that the rate of inflation in Australia is rising to now more than 9 per cent and the rate of inflation in America is falling-last month it was zero-the value of the Australian dollar should logically be falling against the United States dollar. When we look at our second major export market for beef, namely Japan, we find that that country also has zero inflation. Japan has frozen meat prices for at least another year and as our inflation rate rises, costs are rising and that market will also prove less profitable as time goes by. This is despite the fact that the Australian dollar has fallen against the yen by something approaching 40 per cent in the last year.

The other problem that we face all the time is that, as our dollar depreciates, wages faithfully follow the inflationary effects of that depreciation. Obviously we are in a situation where any benefit that has supposedly accrued from the devaluation of the Australian dollar has automatically been wiped out by increased wage costs. We have pointed out to the Government time and time again that if Australia is to maintain its competitiveness, we need to take action on the domestic scene to contain the costs that are being faced by primary producers, both in the wheat and meat industries. The important message that we must get through to the urban areas of Australia is that they are not insulated from the problems facing the export market. It must be realised that in areas of wage fixing, government costs and manufacturing costs, exporters are bearing the brunt. While these areas are being insulated from the real effects of our chronic balance of payments problems, all three are not feeling the same effects of the lack of competitiveness in world trading markets.

While the Opposition welcomes in principle these two Bills which offer a step in the right direction for the statutory marketing bodies-namely the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and the Australian Wheat Board-they are really only of minor importance in dealing with farmers' immediate problems. These problems are twofold. The first is costs-costs that have been imposed by this Government, costs of high interest rates, costs of an inflexible wage system and the cost involved in propping up the dollar above the level to which it would naturally rise. The second is the lack of results in safeguarding our export markets. On the question of meat exports, we should remind ourselves that in the meat industry in particular we are still very heavily exposed in two major markets. Currently 60 per cent of our beef exports go to the United States and 25 per cent to Japan. What is urgently needed-and I call on the Minister to take note of this-is for the Government to look at ways of expanding the number of markets to which we can export. There is no doubt there are many developing countries that would be prepared to take our meat exports, but for various reasons at the moment they are unwilling. The time is now ripe, indeed, the time is now most opportune for the Government to take an aggressive role in these markets and to use our bargaining strength to obtain trade-offs in trade.

These Bills should help consolidate the operations of the AMLC and the AWB. They should encourage the boards to be more commercially oriented, more aggressive in marketing and more successful in meeting the increasingly difficult world trading environment. Naturally, the Opposition supports this.

However, we should not lose sight of the enormous problems facing our rural industries, particularly wheat and meat. We should not lose sight of the fact that so many of these problems have been exacerbated by actions of this Government, actions like forcing up interest rates, forcing an inflexible wages system onto exporters and introducing new taxes and charges that are highly discriminatory against primary producers. Added to this, Australia is seeking the first move by the United States in its trade war with the European Economic Community. Subsidised wheat sales have already been made by the United States to three of our traditional markets. If ever there was a challenge facing the Minister for Trade, it is now. The Prime Minister should direct his Minister to make far more effort to safeguard Australian export markets.

In conclusion, the Opposition will watch closely to see how the amendments to the Wheat Industry Act and the Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act will actually work. We will be monitoring closely in particular how the Minister exercises his power of general direction to the two statutory boards. While these Bills will help in some way, the Government still has many other areas in which it must clean up its act before it and the Minister can say that they are really working for the betterment of these great industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1986 and the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill 1986 address a number of important questions for government. Accountability, the independence of statutory marketing authorities and new technology are involved in the Bills now before the House. I would like to comment on the remarks of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), who strayed slightly from the intent of the Bills. The honourable member assumed that this Government had introduced higher interest rates to hurt primary industry. Not so very long ago this Government was faced with the fact that export receipts were down and domestic demand was still at the same level. This meant that the ratio of imports over exports was too high and there was a tendency for Australians to live beyond their means. The Opposition's simplistic argument, which was mentioned here tonight, was that the Government could have allowed the exchange rate to float still lower. What would this have brought? The demand would still have been with us, inflation and high wage demands would have increased and we would have got back to the Fraser years of wage-price spiralling and an excessive number of industrial disputes and stoppages. SPEECH.PARA: I wish to get back to the intent of the legislation. First of all, the Bills relate to accountability. For example, the Australian Wheat Board will be required to meet annually with the executive of the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation. Because it is not appropriate for members of the executive of the Federation to be members of the Wheat Board, the structure of the Wheat Board has to be changed so that the Board can be accountable to the industry. The legislation also relates to independence. Statutory marketing authorities, which have been with us since the 1920s, were set up in response to market conditions at that time. I recall the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) saying to me when he was the shadow Minister that statutory marketing authorities should no longer be seen as sacred cows in the rural scene.

I know that a lot of people have mentioned the meat industry. However, I would like to mention the wheat industry very briefly. My first job when I left school in the 1950s was as a wheat tester in a flour mill at St Arnaud in the Wimmera. I am not sure whether that area is in the electorate of the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) or the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby). I think it is in the latter electorate. I can recall that there were very big changes in the 1950s. I remember that I did a wheat test on a sample from a place near Sea Lake at Kinnabulla, which I think is in the electorate of the honourable member for Mallee. The quality of that wheat was found to be extremely high. In fact, the manager did not believe that the protein content of the wheat was as I had tested it. He did his own test and found the result to be correct.

You will recall, Madam Speaker, when you and I first met in a chemist shop in the Wimmera in the 1960s. At that time wheat farmers were encouraged by a government which had not recognised Red China. They were encouraged by the Wheat Board-and this showed the true value of the Wheat Board-to go out and sell. They went to Red China, as it was called at that time, and sold. Certainly they created a furore. I remember a local Wheat Board member being investigated by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation because he was saying nice things about the Board's customers. Of course, this was in the pre-Cultural Revolution days. However, farmers came back and praised the dramatic changes that had taken place in China from the 1940s to the 1960s under that nation's new government. They made some excellent sales in China. In the 1980s the Senate Select Committee on Finance and Government Operations made some very important points about statutory marketing authorities-that they were not working as they should be and that they had become bound up, as we all can if we are let go and as has happened in Queensland, which I believe has the highest number of quangos in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —And drongos.

—And drongos. That Senate Committee, under Senator Peter Rae, drew attention to the fact that statutory marketing authorities had become politically and possibly economically constipated. SPEECH.PARA: Today the situation has again changed and the European Economic Community has become a net agricultural exporter instead of importer. We are still finding that governments are attempting to say, as France said not so long ago, that it is cheaper to have people on a small farm growing a small amount of wheat or having a dozen cows than it is to have them on the dole wandering the streets of Paris, but gradually governments are changing their point of view because of pressure from the taxpayers. Excellent work is being done by the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins), the Minister for Primary Industry and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as a result of their visits to the European Economic Community and the United States of America. We have to fight to maintain, much less increase, our market penetration and our Ministers are doing just that. We need a more aggressive approach; we need a better commercial marketing approach. I believe we are doing just that through the legislation that we now have before us. The legislation means more flexibility. It means a greater tendency towards expertise within the executives of these statutory marketing authorities. It also means more flexibility in staffing, more flexibility in the acquiring of property and more flexibility to respond to market forces. Farmers certainly should, as a result of this legislation, be able to minimise production costs which eventually will be reflected in lower costs.

Farm products represent approximately 40 per cent of our exports. People in the cities and in the country towns are only just starting to realise that they are being squeezed simply because we have had low export prices for our primary products. We need to work for more efficiency. Efficiency is more logical than subsidy to farmers. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak to the two Bills before the House, the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation Amendment Bill and the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill, I am reminded that my electorate of Farrer is, in fact, named after Australia's most famous wheat breeder, William Farrer. I am reminded that in fact many of the wheat growers of the electorate of Farrer-indeed, many wheat growers across Australia-and those associated with beef, sheep and a range of meat and livestock products are in dire straits at this time. They suffer from all aspects of a massive rural financial crisis which is gripping so much of Australia. They suffer, in particular, from high interest rates. This is now spilling over to the small business operator in country towns and provincial cities. They are also going into bankruptcy in their hundreds as a consequence of the rural downturn. Therefore, I submit that there is a particular responsibility on this Parliament in considering legislation of this nature to be very conscious of the reality of the situation in rural Australia today. There is a responsibility for members and senators on both sides of the Parliament to utilise those very crowded non-sitting weeks that they have from time to time, especially during the winter recess, to get out and about across rural Australia to see the impact of legislation of this kind before more farmers are forced off the land as a consequence, in part, of the international marketing situation but also very much as a consequence of the policies of the Australian Federal Government.

But I do want to dwell on the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill. Perhaps it is timely to remind the House of the distribution in terms of tonnage production. It might surprise honourable members to learn who were the largest tonnage producers over the last four years. Clearly, New South Wales and Western Australia have a pre-eminent role in terms of the production of the Australian wheat crop, the administrative aspects of which are dealt with by this Bill. Members of the Wheat Board will be exempt so far as their own wheat growing activities are concerned. Again, this points to the difficulty of drafting effective pecuniary interest regulations. This will come up again in regard to members of the House of Representatives in the not too distant future. Compliance dates are rapidly approaching. It points to the very real difficulties, regarding members of the Wheat Board, in arriving at what might be a fundamental conflict of interest associated with their deliberations.

The additional flexibility conferred, on the one hand, by the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill and, on the other, certain of the additional provisions contained in the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill, are not opposed by the Opposition. I support very strongly the comments made by the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), in respect of this legislation. But I remind the Minister, the Government, this House and metropolitan Australia that many primary producers and many small business operators across rural Australia are facing disaster at this time because of the real financial crisis, added to greatly by this Government. I hope that every effort is made to monitor the operation of this legislation closely to ensure that it does not become an added burden to the viability of our primary producers and small business operators in rural Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a great deal of pleasure in rising to speak to these two Bills that are being debated cognately-the Australian Meat and Live-Stock Corporation Amendment Bill 1986 and the Wheat Marketing Bill 1986-because I am very much aware of their significance to primary industry. I am very much aware of the fact that their consideration by the Parliament is probably well overdue. It is not without significance that, in correspondence sent from the Cattle Council of Australia to members of parliament on 30 April 1986, that body indicated its general acceptance of the thrust and the provisions of the Australian Meat and Live-Stock Corporation Amendment Bill 1986. As one of the senior bodies associated with the meat and livestock industry and a commodity council of the National Farmers Federation, the Cattle Council's co-operation during the formulation of this legislation has been of great value. While it is coincidental to the second reading debate, I think it is nevertheless appropriate to draw to the attention of the House the official farewell dinner that is being given by the Cattle Council of Australia for its long time leader, Mr Maurice Binstead. Mr Binstead has been a great leader of the industry, having served it wisely, well and with diligence and great effect over many years. I think I speak for all members in this House in wishing him a long and happy retirement. There is no doubt that his abiding interest in the welfare of the industry will continue. I am sure I speak with the full agreement of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also significant that the two Bills before this House are being debated cognately. When the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) was the shadow Minister in the early 1980s-

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems a long time ago now.

—That is true; my word it does. In 1982 and early 1983, he announced that the Australian Labor Party had formulated policy documents and guidelines for a new organisation for meat marketing. He is also, of course, keen to assist the other primary industry statutory marketing authorities to become more effective instruments for the development of their industries. As he indicated at that time, action had to be taken quickly, as the meat and livestock industry had suffered badly from the meat scandal and also the maladministration of the previous Government, especially under complacency and lack of interest of the then Minister Nixon and, of course, the earlier administration of the man who is the current leader of the National Party of Australia, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). It is to the credit of the then shadow Minister, the present Minister for Primary Industry, that the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation was restructured in 1984 and has worked well since then, as have, of course, the other nine statutory marketing authorities which are in the process of being restructured.

SPEECH.PARA: We are too painfully aware of the harsh trading conditions that are currently being encountered by our primary industry groups. There are other problems, but we recognise that the real seat of the problem lies, of course, in these extremely difficult marketing conditions. We are aware of the problems of reduced returns from export and the expected continuing difficulties that we will encounter, given the restructuring that is taking place in the international community. We recognise that there are markets, that we used to see as considerably appreciative of what we had to offer, that are no longer markets because they are becoming self-sufficient. I refer to markets such as India, which is now a net exporter. Yet I can recall, as a young lad living in Geelong, the number of ships from India that used to take on wheat at the north Geelong silos. In fact, the majority of them seemed to be carting wheat to India. Of course, that does not happen now because, as I said, India is self-sufficient.

We are also concerned, not only with the restructuring that is taking place in that respect internationally, but also the other restructuring of the market-places because of the irresponsible policy of the European Economic Community and the application of aggressive countermeasures-and irresponsible ones-by the United States of America. Among the many measures the Government has undertaken to assist primary industries has been the restructuring of the statutory marketing authorities. Because the statutory marketing authorities concern primary industries that contribute 80 per cent of rural exports, measures to improve their contribution to their respective industry sectors are a matter of great urgency. Of course, that has been recognised by the Minister and the Government. In the White Paper on Reform of Commonwealth Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities of 29 January 1986, the Government adopted a wide range of policies for their restructuring. Of course, these are meeting with the approval of those industry bodies because the industry bodies have been consulted. Of course, the only way in which one can expect these marketing authorities to be able to work for the improvement of the industries is if the industry people are consulted along the way.

Because of the importance of maintaining rural sector profitability and Australia's export performance, the statutory marketing authorities need to operate according to commercial principles to be effective in their highly competitive markets. It should be stated that these statutory marketing authorities were established at the request of the industry sectors. Certainly, they were not imposed by government. Also, as is the case with the two marketing authorities that are the subject of these Bills, they are funded by the industries; they are not funded by the Government. I think it is fitting, therefore, that they are the ones that have a major responsibility for the functioning of those bodies. So the two corporations concerned-that is, the AMLC and the AWB-will assume more responsibility for their own actions. The Bills remove the sometimes frustrating and inefficient requirement for the Minister to approve many aspects of the day to day operations of the Corporation and the Board. These matters have been dealt with, of course, by other speakers.

So far as the Wheat Board is concerned, it can now expand its activities relating to the hedging of wheat sales. It has been doing this, of course, over time, but it needs to be able to do this far more rapidly. It needs to be able to make decisions which become far more effective and that do not need immediate, day to day oversight by the Minister. The Minister is very much aware of this and it is through his wisdom that it has reached this stage. Hedging, of course, needs to be looked at very closely in a whole range of markets and market situations. This is particularly so in the current adverse climate.

There is a range of changes for the day to day activities that the Australian Wheat Board can carry out but, as with the AMLC, the AWB will now be able to make a greater range of decisions regarding purchases of property and terms and conditions of employment of consultants and, of course, the terms and conditions of employment of staff. It is interesting, because I have been discussing this matter this evening with people from the Australian Wheat Board, from the Cattle Council of Australia and also the Livestock and Grain Producers Association. They are very conscious of the problems that have been associated with tying the salaries of these people who are to be the top management people to the Public Service conditions. I am sure that there are many other statutory authorities that the Commonwealth has within its ambit that in fact are faced with the same kind of problem, that one cannot go out in the market-place and expect people to drop thousands and thousands of dollars to take up a position with a statutory marketing authority, or any other government commission or statutory authority. That is something which some people within the Government itself ought to recognise as applies to some of the other statutory authorities.

So, the AMLC will also be able to borrow in excess of $5m in any financial year without having the approval of the Federal Treasurer. This will give it greater flexibility in its operations and greater opportunity to go out there and, of course, borrow and extend the range of its activities in a way that it was not able to do before. The AMLC is now also empowered to choose its own bank according to commercial principles-in other words there has been a freeing up of the commercial aspects of the AMLC and of course, the Australian Wheat Board. Subject to a favourable report from the Auditor-General and the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, the AMLC may select its own auditor. That is a bit different because it would have had it imposed upon it before.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is exciting.

—Well, it may not be terribly exciting for the honourable member for Mallee. I am not quite certain what would be exciting to the honourable member for Mallee, but these are realistic issues. These issues come to the core of the whole matter of putting these authorities on a commercial basis. Perhaps, given the history of the laggards of the honourable member's Party, it is no wonder that the honourable member does not see these things as being very important.

SPEECH.PARA: While the Government intends the Minister for Primary Industry to have a general power and direction over the activities of all the Commonwealth primary industry statutory marketing authorities, this power is seen to be a reserve power to be used only in exceptional circumstances. Like the AMLC, the Australian Wheat Board will be required to develop a three to five year corporate plan and annual operational plans which are to be approved by the Minister. This will allow him to have an oversight of the Australian Wheat Board's operations but now at a strategic rather than at a detailed level. That is very important. Once again it gives the operation a flexibility which it did not have before. It gives it a degree of autonomy that it did not have before and is something that the industries require.

At the industry level both statutory marketing authorities must recognise their accountability to the industries that are funding sources for them. That is extremely important. They will have to report to an annual general meeting, as in the case of the AMLC or to a representative meeting, as in the case of the Australian Wheat Board. These restructured boards must face the enormous responsibility of operating according to commercial principles. They have to do this if they are to be effective in the highly competitive market situation we face today. They have been given opportunity to do so and I am quite certain that the goodwill that exists between these bodies and the Government will ensure that determination is there to succeed once they are established. I commend the Bills to the House.

—I shall come back to this point in a moment. Let us not get unduly excited, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—I am not excited. I think the honourable member for Charlton might be and he might cease interjecting.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) did, in addressing this Bill in his very gregarious and outspoken way, insist that the Government has done something for the Australian primary producers and that it was time the Opposition acknowledged just that point. Let me in the House take up the point of the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) who, whilst not detracting from what the honourable member for Capricornia said, simply said that all that the wheat growers and meat producers in Australian want is results. It is results that have been previously short in this House, in fact, they have scarcely trickled through. The Bills before the Parliament tonight are an indication, we acknowledge, of that trickling.

A matter of real concern for the Opposition is a speech delivered on social security legislation, of all things, by the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) in this House on our last sitting day. On that day, the honourable member for Melbourne stated in this House in referring to Opposition promises on primary industry:

No one is disputing-I am certainly not because I come from a rural background originally and that is why I probably understand the lack of mentality of honourable members opposite a little better than most . . .
As if that were not patronising enough towards our farmers, he went on to say:
that there is poverty in the rural areas. We are justified in giving assistance to the poor and to those people who find themselves in hard times due to climatic conditions. I support all that.

These sentiments were later echoed by the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples). Do honourable members opposite not realise that it is not a climatic drought, or a meteorological state of affairs, at least not yet, that is causing the farmers of Australia so much heartache; it is a financial drought. Yet we have honourable members opposite assuming that the cockies are complaining simply because it has not rained. Much has been made by the Government of the value to the farmers of its decision to devalue the Australian dollar. No one denies that. No one on this side of the House has denied it. In fact, credit has been given to the Government for that action, but the value of that devaluation to all Australia's primary producers, but particularly to our exporters and, therefore, to our grain growers who are so affected by this legislation, has been more than countered by the increased inflation rate, rising interest rates and the impact of the size of our foreign debt. It is worth remembering that, were it not for the cosy relationship that this Government currently enjoys with the Australian Council of Trade Unions that is called the accord, some of those very devastating moves on Australian agriculture could have been countered.

The honourable member for Capricornia has been anxious to say that the Government is prepared to act, but we have seen no action on the issues of inflation, interest rates or the size of our foreign debt. The wheat growers, the meat growers, the Federal Opposition and primary producers across Australia welcome these Bills, but they do not provide a solution to the fundamental problems that primary producers are facing. I put to the House that in spite of the difficulties wheat growers are facing, in spite of the opportunities the Bills before the House provide and in spite of the bleak outlook that grain in Australia currently faces, most grain growers cannot get out of the cycle of producing grain because they currently have such high levels of capital investment in grain production and there is an absence of viable alternative crops. These people will go on producing grain and will become Australia's new poor.

Much has been made by previous speakers of the competition that Australian farmers currently face from the United States of America as a result of its farm Bill and from the European Economic Community. No one would deny that. In fact, no one has taken any issue with the point made by the honourable member for Ballarat about the harsh trading climate in which Australia's primary producers currently have to survive. Not even the comment of the honourable member for Ballarat about the Minister's wisdom has been challenged by honourable members opposite. But the point that needs to be borne in mind is that Australian farmers are selling in an already prejudiced market. Subsidies in Europe on primary production average 160 per cent and in the USA 100 per cent; subsidies in Australia average 10 per cent.

We on this side of the House plead not for increased subsidies for Australian farmers but for the Government to take the burden that it has currently placed on the back of primary producers as a result of its policies in the areas of interest rates, inflation rates, its accord with the ACTU and its wage determination direction. No one denies that the difficulties faced in the trading environment are hard and almost intractable in terms of finding an easy solution. But let us see some steps that mean that the Government is genuinely showing its concern for primary production by altering its domestic policies so that the load carried by Australia's primary producers is not so impossibly intense.

I conclude by paying a compliment to the primary producers of Australia. I pick up the comments made by the honourable member for Capricornia who was somewhat critical of the Australian meat industry. He said that quality meat was frequently not available at restaurants and that restaurateurs had indicated that people were reluctant to order particular cuts of meat because they were uncertain about just what result they would have. If honourable members look at Hansard they will find that this is vindicated. The honourable member for Capricornia went on to indicate that even takeaway food outlets should be able to guarantee the standard of meat that is available to consumers. I make the point to the honourable member for Capricornia that I would have thought that quality demanded something of a premium. A person would expect to have a slightly better cut of meat in a restaurant than he would pick up in a takeaway food joint. Be that as it may, the truth is that the Australian meat industry specialises in having grass fed cattle and there is no doubt that elsewhere in the world our meat is envied because the fat structure of our meat tends to be on the outside and can be removed, whereas in other parts of the world with grain fed cattle there is the tendency for fat to be marbled through the meat. The emphasis of Australian producers on grass fed cattle has given Australian consumers a better standard of meat to consume than is generally available across the rest of the world. This emphasis on quality does not end in our meat market. I noticed with interest in the Adelaide Advertiser earlier this year a statement by rural affairs editor, Jim McCarter. He had been interviewing some Americans.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which Advertiser?

—I can get that for the honourable member a little later if it is a matter of some concern. But the long and short of the matter is that Mr Jim McCarter was discussing an interview he had had with American grain growers. They were talking about the standard of grain available on the export market under the Australian label, `Let us hear it from some Americans'. American, Mr Peter Bloom, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I spent 1978 in Australia . . . and I met Sir Leslie Price who sells Australian wheat. When we talked, I felt obliged to defend our system-
that is the American system-
and I did.
Sir Leslie Price is reported to have said to Mr Bloom:
`tell me, how is it that the American farmer can harvest exactly 2 p.c. foreign material?
Mr Bloom said:
Price is telling his buyers there will be no foreign material, and if there is they don't have to pay for it. That is who we are competing with. That's why we store the carry-over from year to year.

I put it to the House that the farmers of Australia are already taking appropriate initiatives to minimise the impact of trade barriers and to ensure that their product does attract markets overseas. What they are looking for is a government prepared not only to introduce this sort of legislation which makes it easier for the farmers to act but also, in addition, to get some of the weight of government administration and domestic administration off the primary producer's back.
