SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to give my support to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) for the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill and the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill and to be honest and to lament that, while in government, the coalition did not enact such legislation. The Minister and his Government have taken a more realistic approach to primary industry statutory marketing authorities by recognising the need to make them more commercially oriented. The Opposition supports that. Greater autonomy, less direct ministerial involvement and a higher level of formal accountability by the Board to the industry are all positive moves and, as I said initially, long overdue. It is also heartening to see that the Government is to ensure that the Wheat Board provides a corporate and operational plan defining the principal objectives of the Board as well as staggering the terms of office of the members. While I applaud the move to make the Wheat Marketing Board more commercially competitive, I must express disappointment at the lack of Government initiative for overcoming the fundamental macroeconomic problems facing agriculture and the economy generally.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister in his recent economic and rural policy speech failed to address several major issues affecting not only the rural producers but also our manufacturing sector. Is it not about time the Government came clean with its approach to the J-curve and macroeconomics? The fundamental problems with the economy are not being tackled. As a result of this Government's actions in hiding behind the trendy economic jargon of the day, our export markets are being hamstrung by our high interest rates, inflation rate and poor productivity. On the one hand we are saying to the Wheat Marketing Board that it should go out and compete on the world market while on the other we are straddling it with an artificial economic situation at home. If we are serious about making the Australian Wheat Board, the Meat and Livestock Corporation or any other statutory body more competitive, we need to become more serious about our domestic affairs.

In a question to the Minister which I placed on notice recently-he is a Minister who takes questions on notice seriously and answers them, unlike some other Ministers-I asked him whether the net returns to wheat growers from 1982-83 to 1984-85 were below the consumer price index for the corresponding years. The answer was a resounding yes. How can our products compete on the world market if we are subjecting our farmers to higher and higher costs? We export over 80 per cent of our domestic wheat. However, in the world context this amount is a proverbial drop in the bucket. While the export market is important to the individual Australian farmer, on the international scale our Board has very little commercial strength.

We can give our Wheat Marketing Board more competitive strength by improving labour productivity. This requires relating payments directly to performance, abandoning automatic wage indexation increases and introducing more flexibility in the setting of wages. However, the Minister has decided, or it was decided for him, not to tackle these issues and to stick to the current centralised wage fixing system. It is such a pity, especially when no less a person than the Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Bernie Fraser, has come out in favour of greater flexibility in order to reduce labour costs and improve our competitiveness. He has been reported as saying that flexibility was vital to improvements in the crucial area of labour costs but that this would require modifications to the centralised wage-fixing system. This is something the Opposition has put forth on numerous occasions.

Both sides of this House are aware our current high interest rates are a result of the Government funding its own deficit. Until we can get interest rates down we will continue to be uncompetitive in both our agricultural and manufacturing sectors. To say that our high interest rates can be blamed on domestic demand without acknowledging excessive governmental demand is to hide from the basic cause of our international competitiveness. The sharp spurt in inflation of up to 9.2 per cent in the latest consumer price index figures for the March quarter will increase pressure on the Government to make large real cuts in its spending programs. Giving the Wheat Board more autonomy and thereby enabling the Board to repay to the Commonwealth moneys expended during 1985 is a step in the right direction. We need to give more marketing boards this independence.

The recent rainfalls in Victoria, South Australia and parts of New South Wales and Queensland have been welcomed by farmers and urban dwellers alike. The fear of another drought is prevalent in our rural communities. When combined with the fear of high interest rates and depressed world commodity markets, the psychological effects are devastating. The Government, in its rural package, acknowledged the need for counselling for farmers and their families. This will be of some assistance to the distraught, but what is really needed is stability in our economic situation.

There is a growing awareness that Australia's farm crisis is arising out of a growing mismatch between what we like to produce and what the world needs. The Government and farm industry leaders need to look at catering to the growing demand in our South East Asian markets for a greater variety of foodstuffs. With estimates of between 4,000 and 5,000 farmers being forced out of wheat growing, there is no alternative but to look to a comprehensive re-assessment of agriculture in Australia. We can no longer afford to have our farmers eking out a living by producing food for which there is no real market. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has reported that the average farm cash operating surplus was expected to decline by $6,500 in 1985-86. One of the reasons for this decline is the increase in farm cash costs, which have risen by over $10,000 since 1983-84. The rate of return to capital and management will drop close to zero this financial year against 2 per cent last year. The decline in average receipts for crops fell even more dramatically-by 14 per cent-last year and are predicted to fall a further 5 per cent this year. Our farmers have a right to be angry. The band-aid approach used for so long to our problems in the bush needs to be halted and a complete reappraisal of anticipated trends of world agricultural trade is needed. From this basis a suitable production structure and marketing strategy may be possible.

I now turn my attention to the foreshadowed royal commission into the handling, storage and transport of grains. I draw the Minister's attention to the Australian Agricultural Council's sub-committee inquiry into off-farm costs. The following question must be asked: What is the need for a royal commission before the findings of that sub-committee are known? That, to my understanding, will be in July. It would appear to be rather extravagant at this stage for the Government to commence with the royal commission inquiry prior to the release of this sub-committee's findings.

As a footnote comment on this matter, I must say that it is a pity that all factions dealing with the storage, handling and transport of grain cannot work together to make this industry more profitable. Our farmers are the most efficient in the world, but their backup support lets them down at critical times. It is time we all began working together to overcome these difficulties so our products can reach their destination on time and in good condition. The Bill sets up a consultative procedure to ensure that the Board has had an opportunity to put its views to the Minister. The 50,000-tonne sale, which the United States has made, will deprive Australian growers of about $10m in revenue. The United States has used a $US20 a tonne subsidy to undercut the Australian Wheat Board by about $US2 a tonne. Of course we know that the United States is pursuing some of these policies simply to counter the EEC. The cost of the food mountain at present in the common market commodity pricing system is about $6 billion, which is a fivefold increase over the past four years. The surpluses continue to rise at an alarming rate and the recent entry of Spain into the EEC, just over three months ago, has already added an additional 1.5 million tonnes of barley to the grain mountain. The EEC farm Ministers, in giving unwarranted generous farm price increases in past years, leave the EEC Commission with no room to manoeuvre. Of course, the Minister was prepared to bring down a document that was cosmetic in that all it did was appease those concerns of those city dwellers. It did not address the real problems of rural Australia. The real problems of rural Australia will be dealt with only if this Government is prepared to do a number of things. The first thing which it must be prepared to do and which will probably give immediate benefit is to get out of the interest rate market. The Government, quite self-admittedly, says that its monetary policy is adding to the cost of interest rates throughout Australia. It is reported that some 6 to 7 per cent is added to our interest rates because of the Government's monetary policy. This is the one area that the Government could act on to give immediate relief to those people in rural Australia today.

Living up the road from my own farm in Young is a fellow by the name of Chris Beck, of whom I have spoken in this Parliament before and who was on the Willesee show only the other night. Some three years ago Chris Beck borrowed a large amount of money at about 12 per cent interest. Today he is paying 22 per cent interest. Because of that he is paying $120,000 interest over and above what he originally started out paying. This has all come about not because of the dumping attitudes of the EEC or the United States or, as the Minister likes to point out, the policies of the Fraser-Anthony Government, but because of this Government's monetary policy. I am afraid that until the Government is prepared to turn that decision around it will not be able to give immediate relief to the farmers of Australia, unless it is prepared to offer them large and expensive subsidies. I am quite sure that the majority of farmers in Australia do not want large and expensive subsidies; they just want to get a Government policy off their backs. This is a Government policy which, in the case of my constituent at Young, Chris Beck, is costing him $120,000. That is the difference between being in business and being out of business. These people really do need a fair go.

Instead of giving a fair go, the rural aid package handed back to the rural community only about one-quarter of what has been taken by this Government since it has been in power. In fact, the rural aid package has lost all its credibility because of the statements of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in the Senate. The Minister for Finance said that the centrepiece of the rural aid package, the axing of the quarantining of farm losses, would not take place and that in fact anybody who claimed, as the Minister for Primary Industry did claim, that axing it would give a $65m a year benefit to the rural community was exaggerating. That is what the Minister for Finance said. I am afraid that has thrown the entire rural aid package into a state of lack of credibility. In fact, as a result of that statement there is still confusion right throughout the rural communities-confusion which is stopping people who might be buyers of rural properties from buying those properties. Until the Government is prepared to decrease interest rates, until it is prepared to remove the confusion surrounding the axing of the quarantining of farm losses, until it scraps capital gains taxes, until it allows the Australian dollar to float freely, until it passes on the full benefits of the world-wide reduction in the price of fuel, I am afraid that the good news we have tonight for the rural industry will be the only good news we will get from this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about 1986?

SPEECH.PARA: Meat and Live-stock Amendment Bill

Whereas the previous Government was working on the principle of subsidies and cutting down subsidies, we have given commercial flexibility.

The honourable member for Farrer also said that the procedure for settling any dispute about the annual operating plan is really pretty straight forward. I am not a lawyer. It says that, if there is any disagreement, they are simply told that I write back to them and that then we settle it. That is what that language means. The Minister, too, has to be accountable. SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) carried on about a few usual sorts of complaints, trying to denigrate the Prime Minister in his efforts overseas and saying that there is this great media build-up and this great hype and all the rest of it. -Order! If honourable members wish to get on to the adjournment debate, if the Minister is heard in silence we will get there more quickly. If the Minister is not heard in silence, I will ask the Minister to resume his seat and this could take longer than we expect.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first opportunity available to me to respond to comments by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in replying to a question without notice that I asked on Friday. My question focused on the yawning gap in this country's balance of payments-a deficiency of the order of $1,000m per month or over $30m on tick every day, in a context of rising inflation. This the Government treats with equanimity and gaily proceeds with is profligate spending programs; after all the present annual cost of the community employment program on this reckoning is only about 10 days' borrowing at $30m a day!

SPEECH.PARA: The principal point I want to take up is the Treasurer's blinkered and totally erroneous suggestion that the present yawning balance of payments deficit is in some way a legacy of the previous Government. The Treasurer correctly states that the balance of payments deficit in 1981-82 was very large, amounting to the order of 6 per cent of gross domestic product. However, he is having himself on-to use a paraphrase for a word that the Speaker ruled as unparliamentary last Friday-in attributing that deficit primarily to the currency appreciation to mid-1981 and the admitted increase in wages; rather, the predominant cause was the surge in private investment by business firms in this country under the sound economic policies of the previous Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You blew the resources boom.
—Order! The honourable member for Calwell will cease interjecting.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The large scale importation of machinery and equipment, feeding, so to speak, a significant expansion of real business investment and reflected in a large balance of payments deficit-with that deficit substantially financed by the moneys borrowed to fund the investment-is a very proper phenomenon, a classic current balance of payments deficit situation. That was widely recognised in the economic literature of the time and not least the Information Paper on the Economy issued with the National Economic Summit Conference in 1983. At page 117 of that document it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The increases in the current account deficit over that period, 1979-80 to 1981-82 reflected: `A surge of investment in energy related development projects . . .

That is first and primary. It then goes on to refer to other factors, to `some erosion of Australia's international competitiveness' reflecting the Australian dollar's appreciation and the increase in wages, and to `the international recession which meant weaker world demand and prices for most of Australia's exports'.

The Treasurer is simply rewriting history in not recognising the primacy of the investment aspect. Further, I remind the Treasurer and the Government that that was the last occasion that private business investment did make a positively strong contribution to real growth in the economy and to the future development of productive capacity and rising living standards. The Treasurer tabled a paper today from Budget Paper No. 1 this year. Similarly I refer to the tables on pages 15, 19 and 20 the same paper which bear on the point I am making. Not that I need to do that: Mr Simon Crean, the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, said it all for me at a recent business seminar as reported in the Australian only last Thursday, 1 May, when he said that business investment was `in an abysmal state'. An important thrust of my question last Friday was precisely that the present vast `spending on tick' overseas is being blown on consumption purposes rather than investment resulting in the growth of productive capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the House's attention to the problem of unemployment benefit payments and to draw a comparison between the amount wage earners received after they have paid their tax and the amount received by those who are in receipt of that benefit. A constituent in Corangamite has drawn my attention to such a comparison in open case. This constituent has experience in the personnel area. He has drawn to my attention the fact that an unskilled labourer in the Geelong area is paid from $235 to $268 for a 38-hour week. Person A, who works the 38-hour week, receives approximately $245 and, after paying his due tax of $29, union fees of $1.75 and the cost of transport to and from work of $5, receives in his final pay packet $209 per week. Person B receives the unemployment benefit for himself and his wife of $163.30 and, if he has two dependent children, he receives $16 each, or $32 altogether, for those children and a rental subsidy on his housing commission home of $10. His final income is $205.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the comparison between those two persons. The first works 38 hours, has to turn up punctually for work, has to pay the cost of his transport and has to act in a responsible manner. The second person does not do any work, does not have to meet any deadlines, can turn up at any time to any part of Geelong and, what is more, receives a 50 per cent rebate in his transport costs. A further complicating factor in this comparison is that the person who receives the unemployment benefit can receive cash payments of up to $50 a day for casual work in the Geelong area. I am led to believe that that is about the going rate. He pays no tax and still retains his unemployment benefit, so obviously his net position is a lot better than that of the first person.

I suggest that the first solution is, obviously, to reduce the rate of taxation so that the person in work who works overtime to receive more money is paying no more than 30c in the dollar. Secondly, we ought to be looking at a program to provide penalties for those people who pay their employees cash in hand. Thirdly, we should review the method and scale of payments of the unemployment benefit. The Budget figures which the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) drew to the attention of the House show that the unemployment benefit cost $3,495m in one year out of a social security budget of $19,077m, about 27 per cent of the total Budget. The Economic Planning Advisory Council, an adviser to the Government, in its booklet No. 17 entitled `Growth in Australian Social Expenditures', had this to say about that problem:

Increased coverage of unemployment benefits does not reflect policies designed to extend coverage, but rather an increasing tendency for the unemployed to apply for unemployment benefit. This in turn is probably due to: the increased average duration of unemployment; changes in social attitudes towards acceptance of unemployment benefit; and increases in the numbers induced into claiming, and preferring to stay on benefits by improvements in levels and conditions of benefit themselves.

I think that sums up the situation. A very authoritative advisory body to the Government has put forward the problem. I am suggesting and my constituent in Corangamite is suggesting that we employ people in a productive capacity rather than allowing them to lean on the taxpayers for handouts and that we endeavour to change attitudes and policies to ensure that the growing national debt of $80 billion can be paid off in the near future.
